TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make the following statement to the Senate concerning my contact with Mr Greg Symons, following recent publicity about the matter. I returned to the Senate on Monday, 4 May 1992, having been absent during the previous sitting week. The two questions which were asked in the Senate concerning Senator Richardson's contacts with Mr Greg Symons—one on Monday, 4 May and then one on Wednesday, 6 May—caused me to recall that I had met Mr Symons last year, but I did not at that time connect that meeting with the matters which were then being raised.

PARA.TAB: On 7 May, the last day of sitting, a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, concerning dealings between Mr Symons and the Australian Embassy or consulates in the United States, prompted me to recall that I may have done something to put Mr Symons in contact with the Australian Embassy in Washington. After Question Time I asked my staff to conduct a search for any relevant information. Due to pressure of business we were not able to return to the matter on 7 May. On 8 May my staff informed me that a letter from me to Mr Chris Lamb, Congressional Liaison Officer, Australian Embassy, Washington, had been located, and a copy of the letter was provided to me on the following day.

It was then clear to me that, in view of the question which was asked in the Senate on 7 May, I should make a statement to the Senate on the matter on the next day of sitting. On 13 May the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) asked me to provide to him a statement on my contact with Mr Symons, in view of the publicity then being given to Senator Richardson's contact with him. As the Prime Minister's press statement on that day indicated, he is not in a position to require me to provide such a report, but I agreed to do so to assist him in his consideration of the matter.

Bearing in mind my responsibility to the Senate, I contacted all party leaders and Independent senators at the first opportunity to advise them that I would be reporting to the Prime Minister. I provided the report to the Prime Minister on 15 May and shortly afterwards I provided the report and the attached documents to the leaders of the parties in the Senate and the Independent senators. I also made the report and attachments public.

On 21 May I learnt that an acknowledgment of my letter of 20 November to Mr Lamb had been received on 10 December. This acknowledgment, which had not been shown to me, was incorrectly filed and was therefore inadvertently omitted from the original report. As a result, a change needed to be made to the report as shown in the attached documents.

I have set out these matters in some detail in order to assure the Senate that I have been mindful of my obligation to report to the Senate on my knowledge of this matter, and I am now doing so at the first available opportunity. As the matters I have set out make clear, it was not possible for me to report to the Senate earlier. I now table all relevant material.

That consideration of the President's statement be called on at the conclusion of question time this day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, there has been a lot of comment in the press about this issue, particularly in the last few days. This week, Westpac and the State Bank of New South Wales have both reduced their business reference rates by two percentage points. PARA.TAB: The action by these banks has been prompted by the move last week by the National Australia Bank to target business borrowers—a strategy which the Government welcomes. The National Australia Bank has set aside a $1 billion fund for lending to small and medium sized businesses. Its reference rate is as low as 8.25 per cent. The State Bank of New South Wales has said that it will commit $500m to its plan to target the small and medium business sector. Both these moves have to be welcomed in an environment in which there has been a shortage of capital, particularly for small and medium sized businesses. I expect and hope that the Commonwealth Bank and the ANZ Bank will soon be forced to match these offers, as will the smaller banks.

The lowering of business interest rates reflects further dividends from the progress that has been made in reducing inflation and inflationary expectations. I suspect that this is one of the reasons for Dr Hewson's intemperate attack on a Reserve Bank official last week. Any good news is unwelcome to the Leader of the Opposition. In a quite bizarre reversal of traditional practice, the bearers of good news are to be put to the sword by Dr Hewson, apparently, in support of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the imaginative speech writer?

ANSWER.PARA: While I doubt it is possible to achieve a major reduction in inflation without a contraction in output, it is possible to have a recession that has little or no favourable impact on inflation.

That is an issue which we debated in the Senate a couple of weeks ago. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister's memory to my question of him on 7 May last when he refused my request for him to investigate his own Department to ascertain and report to the Senate upon any dealings between Mr Symons and the Australian Embassy or consulates in the United States of America. Would the Minister explain to the Senate why it was necessary for the Prime Minister to initiate a search of the Minister's departmental files; and why did the Minister fail in his responsibility to make himself aware of his Department's involvement in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop will recall the reason why I declined to assist her on 7 May. I spelt that out at some length in the supplementary exchange we had after Question Time, which appears in Hansard at page 2460. The reason of course, as I stated to her then, was that the question as asked of me raised on its face no obvious question of public affairs, nothing justifying the kind of fishing expedition or dragnet expedition that she was inviting me to undertake. I said that, until such time as I got some foundation for pursuing such an investigation, I would not do so. That is the basis, of course, on which I responded to her question then, and that response remains an entirely credible one.

PARA.TAB: The course of events that occurred which led to these various matters coming to light was as follows: my office was, of course, monitoring Question Time when Senator Bishop's question was asked of me. My senior adviser rang the Department and asked whether it had any knowledge as to what Senator Bishop might be on about. He asked that question of the South Pacific branch of the Department, that being the one associated with the Marshall Islands. The officers in the Department in question said that there may be something in the records; they had some recollection of it. They, as a result, went back to their material and faxed across to my ministerial office a bundle of papers, which I then saw when I returned to my office—I had no previous knowledge of it—around about 4 o'clock on 7 May.

Those papers included specifically Senator Sibraa's letter to Mr Lamb in our Embassy in Washington and immediately, as a result, raised the possibility that there had been such a contact between Mr Symons and the Washington Embassy, if not necessarily any other US mission of ours. It being at that stage night-time in the United States, it was not possible to follow up then and there with the US—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you just went to bed.

—It was the middle of the night in the United States, and, the next morning, Australian time, being business hours in the United States, a phone call was made from my Department to Mr Lamb in Washington which elicited the information that yes, indeed, Senator Sibraa's letter had been followed up; there had been an exchange between Mr Lamb, Mr Symons and a Mr Paul Finch a few days afterwards; that Mr Lamb had, as a result of that exchange, advised them that there was nothing that the Australian Government could usefully do to assist them directly and that they should pursue the matter themselves; and they were given some United States officials' phone numbers to follow up in that respect. That was where the matter rested so far as Mr Lamb and the Washington Embassy were concerned.

PARA.TAB: I then was told of this on Friday, the 8th. I asked my office to get the Department to put all of that in memo form and, when the memo was received, I asked that it pass that on to the Prime Minister's office, to discuss the handling of the question with the PM's office and, if anything else needed following up, then to follow it up. That is the instruction I left behind me as I left Canberra on Friday afternoon to go back to Melbourne, from where I left for overseas on the following day, the Saturday.

Such a follow-up did in fact occur in the course of consultations over the next few days and, as will be recalled, the Prime Minister on the 13th—the following Wednesday—did in fact set in train a formal report from Senator Richardson and Senator Sibraa. In the context of that process, some further following up was done by my Department with Washington and, indeed, other US consulates, just to ensure that there had been no other point of contact.

Mr Lamb was asked to produce not just an oral account of what had occurred, but to forward a memo, which he duly did. Mr Lamb, who by that time had, of course, gone back to his files and not just relied on memory in responding orally, discovered the particular document—the apparent memo from Mr Symons to Senator Richardson. Mr Lamb attached that to his memo and sent it back to Australia that week, 15 May, under cover of his own memo dated 14 May.

It was on that basis that, for the first time, this material—that particular memo—came to the attention of my Department. I am happy to table the memo to which I am referring—the memo that was sent from Mr Lamb back to the Department—together with its attachments, being the memo in question from Symons to Richardson and also a copy of the letter that Mr Lamb wrote on 4 December.

I think, Mr President, that explains the sequence of events. I had no knowledge whatsoever of any documentation bearing upon this matter at the time that I answered the question as I did in the Senate. The mere asking of that question generated a course of events which I have described now in full. It produced the documentation to which I have referred and that is really about the extent of it.

While I am on my feet—lest there be any question arise of me having misled the Senate in any possible respect in this matter—might I say that there are a couple of further documents which turned up in the course of the Department's research into this matter. As honourable senators would expect, the Department has been very assiduously researching it in the run up to this week. That was a file note and a fax cover sheet dated 6 April in the Department's records which indicate that my senior adviser was advised by a departmental officer by telephone back on 6 April that two Australian citizens, namely Symons and Finch, had been arrested and charged with forgery in the Marshall Islands and that there were rumours that Senator Richardson had phoned the RMI Government about that matter—unsurprising rumours, since in fact he had around that day, as everyone knows.

Secondly, the note indicates that in the context of this call there had been reference to Symons's contact with the Washington Embassy and that the Department had, moreover, faxed across to my office six bits of paper—a Marshall Islands news report about the arrests and the same five documents that the Department later faxed to me on 7 May. Those documents were a memo from Washington covering the Sibraa letter, the attachment to the Sibraa letter and an exchange of faxes with our Ambassador in Pohnpei.

Obviously, my answer on 7 May would have been different—it certainly should have been different—if I had been aware of any of that material and any of the contact with my office that that file note implies. But I was not aware of it. My senior adviser has only the barest recollection of the conversation in question on 6 April except as it related to the arrests. He has no recollection whatsoever of seeing any of the faxed documents. My office has no record of those faxes, and a thorough search has failed to turn them up. I was not advised of the conversation, let alone saw any of the documents that might have been sent following it. Lest there be any disposition to get excited about any of this, I asked my senior adviser to swear a statutory declaration as to these matters, which he has duly done, which I now table and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you tabling the file notes?
—No.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: I, Miles Kupa, Public Servant, of 94 Schlich Street, Yarralumla, in the Australian Capital Territory, do solemnly and sincerely declare that the following sets out my recollections of when and how I became aware of the contact in November 1991 between the Australian Embassy in Washington and Mr Greg Symons:

1. On the afternoon of 7 May, after Senator Evans had told Senator Bishop in the Senate, in response to a question, that he was not aware of any dealings between Symons and the Australian Embassy or consulates in the United States, I telephoned Mr O'Leary, AS SPB in the Department, to establish if the Department knew of any such dealings.

2. Mr O'Leary replied that there may have been such dealings, in Washington. Senator Sibraa had written to the Embassy to ask if it could facilitate meetings for Mr Symons in Washington. A copy of this letter had been sent by the Embassy to the Department at the time. In the context of a telephone conversation with me in early April (Note: 6 April), about Mr Symons's court appearance in the Marshall Islands, he had mentioned the possibility of a meeting between Mr Symons and the Washington Embassy and had referred to the Sibraa letter. He had then faxed some documents about the Symons case, including a copy of Senator Sibraa's letter, to this Office.

3. In response I said that I had had no memory of this early April conversation, other than that it related to Symons's court case, but that, while he had been talking about Washington to me, a recollection of some reference on his part to a Symons-Washington connection in the earlier conversation had come to me. However, I did not recall him having referred at that time to a letter from Senator Sibraa. Nor did I recall seeing a copy of such a document, which I thought I would have. I asked Mr O'Leary to undertake a check of his Branch's files and to send copies of the documents relating to the possibility of contact between Mr Symons and the Washington Embassy to me as soon as possible.
4. Mr O'Leary undertook to do so and later that afternoon the documents (copies attached, marked A to F), including a copy of Sibraa's letter, were sent to the Office and I received them.
5. I have no recollection of seeing the documents, including the Sibraa letter, prior to their receipt in the Office on the afternoon of 7 May.

6. I conveyed the documents to Senator Evans later that afternoon, after his second exchange with Senator Bishop in the Senate. I had not informed Senator Evans earlier of my 6 April conversation with O'Leary—Senator Evans was overseas from 5-12 April—and there was no information given to Senator Evans by this Office (or to my knowledge by anyone else) that would have made him aware of a possible Symons contact with Washington before he answered Senator Bishop's question on 7 May.
Attachments A to F are attached.

I make this solemn declaration by virtue of the Statutory Declarations Act 1959 as amended and subject to the penalties provided by that Act for the making of false statements in statutory declarations, conscientiously believing the statements contained in this declaration to be true in every particular.
Declared at Canberra on 26 May 1992(Sgd) MILES KUPA

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't do, Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Perhaps it was the speed of the delivery of the Minister, but I wonder whether he could just say something again, in case I misunderstood. I think he said that he informed Senator Richardson but he did not inform the Senate or me. Is that right? Could you ask him to make that clear, Mr President?
—Order! It is not a point of order, but if Senator Bishop is having difficulty hearing, perhaps the Minister could repeat it.

—It was a little difficult to inform the Senate on Friday, 8 May because the Senate was not sitting on that day. It was on that basis that I thought there may be a necessity for the matter to be further followed up, and certainly in preparation for when the Senate resumed, and I gave instructions accordingly. As a result, the matter was followed up in the way that I have described.
—I ask the Minister to table the file note to which he referred, which was the one, I think, that made reference to Senator Richardson.

—No, Mr President. I have described its content accurately enough. In that respect, quite a large number of documents have accumulated, particularly in the context of the arrests of the two Australian citizens, the subsequent consular advice and assistance, of an entirely normal kind, that has been given to them, and in relation to matters going to the substance of the charge that these particular gentlemen are facing in the Marshall Islands. PARA.TAB: I am not going to respond to requests to table every one of those documents because there are very real difficulties about doing so. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the survival plan for the ANM Mill at Boyer in Tasmania which was drawn up by agreement between management and employees? Does this survival plan depend, among other things, on changes to work practices which were negotiated between management and the unions on site at Boyer? Are these unions basically the same as those operating at APPM in Burnie, where management is refusing to talk to unions and employees about these issues? Can the Minister advise honourable senators why there is such a difference between the industrial relations approach of these two companies and what the consequences of the differences are?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first three questions is yes, yes and yes. Australian Newsprint Mills at Boyer faced grave economic difficulties and decided to take a sensible approach by bringing its work force into its confidence about what those difficulties were and by hammering out with its employees a survival plan for the company and for their security of employment as well. This is in stark contrast to the activities of APPM which, at Burnie in northern Tasmania, took a totally different course of action. APPM could be styled as a company with a death wish, or called a company intent on making itself an industrial relations pariah in this country.

PARA.TAB: I return to ANM, which is an example of best practice by an Australian company seeking to be world competitive with its product. It has undertaken the necessary restructuring of its operation in order to do so. What did ANM do? It drew up a survival plan in 1985; it injected another $280m of capital investment to upgrade its plant and equipment; it introduced a new management approach—total quality management; it invested heavily in research and development. It looked at product diversity—what it sells to the market—and moved to a higher grade paper products line. It conducted, with its employees, award restructuring and improved the work practices in the company. It introduced a new human resources management approach which emphasised career pathing for employees, skills acquisition and multi-skilling so that the work force could be more flexibly deployed given the advent of new technology.

It achieved these changes through consultation with its work force. In the early stages there was some dispute over the process and the detail but they have settled down, hammered together and produced a plan which will mean that this company is restructured to put it on a pathway to being one of the world's best, to meet world and global competition and to be relevant to the demands of its market. And it did it harmoniously, in consultation with its employees.

One of the questions asked of me was: are these the same unions that are on site at APPM? The answer is yes. There are 11 unions at the ANM works; they are the same unions as at APPM. The significant ones at APPM are the PKIU, MEWU, the ETU and the FEDFA. All of those unions and their representatives have been involved in the survival package at ANM.

In December 1991, ANM was nominated by the Australian best practice panel as a best practice company and supported by me. ANM is now recognised among Australian companies as a model of how to conduct award restructuring and orientate a company to be globally competitive. As I have said, this stands in stark contrast to the high-handed activities of APPM at Burnie. APPM has succeeded in alienating its work force, making war on the community of Burnie and destroying its own economic base as a commercial operation. In fact, it has engaged in an approach to industrial relations—

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like the Building Workers Industrial Union.

—Senator Kemp interjects in a way favourable to the management of APPM. This simply reflects that both Senator Kemp and APPM are afficionados of the H. R. Nicholls Society and the ultra right wing approach to confrontation in the Australian workplace.

PARA.TAB: APPM has not enlisted the support and cooperation of its employees. It has sued a number of its employees at common law and it is claiming damages from them. It has taken a writ of mandamus against the Tasmanian police to require them to take action to arrest the workers. APPM has rejected the cooperative approach that the workers have offered to help restructure the company and it has unilaterally overridden it in a high-handed way. Clearly, this company, which claims to want to talk to its workers, has no interest at all in building a cooperative basis and restructuring.

I conclude by referring to the Sunday Tasmanian dated 26 April 1992 which quoted Ms Julie Fraser, a mother of four, previously uninterested in industrial relations matters, never a member of a union but now an organiser of the Support Pulp Employees Committee, as follows:
Mrs Fraser said intimidation of APPM workers had increased since the start of the dispute and tensions between workers even extended to members of the same family.
"I'm at a loss to understand what the workers have done to deserve the treatment they are getting".

ANSWER.PARA: This is an ordinary Australian, a member of the Burnie community not previously interested in these matters, who, along with the rest of that community, has been radicalised into action against this rogue company.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What criteria guided the Prime Minister, then the Treasurer, to draw such a sharp distinction between the Fitzgerald inquiry and the WA royal commission with respect to access to tax information held by the Tax Office? What was the effect on the two inquiries of this difference in treatment? Is it not a fact that access by the Fitzgerald inquiry was filtered through the discriminatory power of the Commissioner of Taxation and, therefore, could not be likened to ripping off the lid of the Tax Office? How many tax records were disclosed to the Fitzgerald inquiry? Was it less than 100? Finally, will the WA royal commission now get precisely the same access to tax relevant information as the Fitzgerald inquiry and, if not, why is a distinction still being drawn?

—I do not have a copy of the Prime Minister's statement on this matter, which was made a week or so ago, but I will certainly get hold of it and I hope that that will provide an answer to the last part of the question.As far as the first part of the question about differential access is concerned, my understanding is that in each case the Treasurer of the day was acting on the advice of the Commissioner of Taxation. I will get confirmation of that, but that is my understanding of the matter.As to how many tax records were disclosed to the Fitzgerald inquiry, that is a question which I will have to take on notice. I will obtain that information as soon as I can and provide it to Senator Coulter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say I am a little surprised at the inadequacy of the Minister's answer in view of the fact that this has been very prominent in the news over some weeks. Therefore, I ask by way of a supplementary question whether the Government will ensure that the WA royal commission will get precisely the same access to the tax relevant information as was given to the Fitzgerald inquiry. Will the Minister give that undertaking?

—My understanding is that the Western Australian royal commission will get the information which it wants, but I will obtain clarification of that in respect of any detail which Senator Coulter might like to put to me. Some parts of his question require very detailed information. I said that I will obtain that information and I will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. When the Government's car plan began in 1984 the Minister identified improvements in the quality of Australian made cars as an important aim for the industry and the Government. Can the Minister advise the Senate of any evidence of an improvement in quality levels?

—This would normally be regarded as what is called a dorothy dix question, except that Senator Foreman has for a very long time maintained a keen interest in the automotive industry and everything that happens regarding it. The answer to the honourable senator's question can be seen in the showrooms across Australia. The latest evidence of improvement in quality is in the Wheels magazine's annual quality rating which, as the word `annual' implies, is done every year.
—Very good!

—I am getting better. That rating is published in the latest issue. Every year it rates 20 of our top selling cars in a survey carried out with the assistance of the NRMA in New South Wales and Total Quality Ltd. Ranking is based on inspection of vehicle qualities. Wheels reports what it calls a big surge in quality by Australian car makers, big enough to earn them five of the top 10 positions in terms of automotive quality of cars sold in Australia. I think it is the first time in Australia that that result has been obtained. It confirms the findings of the Automotive Industry Authority in its report on the state of the automotive industry which was tabled in the Senate two or three weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: As I said, Wheels bases its assessments on examinations of new cars by experts. The Automotive Industry Authority, of course, points out that the customer is the ultimate arbiter of quality, but it bases its comments on the assessments made by car owners several months after they have taken delivery of new vehicles. The Automotive Industry Authority estimated that the quality of Australian made vehicles had improved 27 per cent over the four years to the time of its report recently tabled in the Senate. The report also states that the quality gap between locally manufactured cars and comparable imports has narrowed significantly. In 1991, the quality of seven out of the eight locally produced models improved; the quality of the eighth model remained unchanged.

This sort of improvement is crucial to the future of the Australian car industry. Before the Government's car plan, local manufacturers did not pay enough attention to quality. They are increasingly doing so. In 1992, the industry is aware of its importance to sales, profits and employment.

Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, sure. It is just a suggestion coming from our Embassy in Pohnpei which has picked up the rumours and is passing them on to us. —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation to two incidents last month in which ships trading with Australia were boarded by pirates in the Singapore Straits and members of the crew assaulted. Apparently, this is not unique. Can the Minister advise of action being taken to address concerns within the shipping industry over the rise in the number of piracy attacks?

—I regret to advise the Senate that there has been a disturbing increase in the incidence of piracy against shipping in South East Asia, which has now provoked international attention. Along with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, I have received representations from the Australian Chamber of Shipping and the Australian National Maritime Association expressing their extreme concern at the situation. Apart from the immediate threat to the safety of the ships' crews, there is also the possibility of a vessel being disabled and, therefore, posing a severe environmental threat. This was demonstrated recently when a fully laden tanker was boarded by pirates. The crew were tied up and the pirates then laid fires in the accommodation area and the engine room of the ship. Fortunately the crew were able to free themselves and extinguish the fire, but not before the vessel had been disabled for some time.

PARA.TAB: In recent incidents, the container vessel Australia Star was boarded by pirates as it left the Straits of Singapore. The crew were threatened with machetes and money was stolen from the ship's safe. A week later the Australian tanker Osco Star was similarly raided and the ship's safe was also robbed. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority provided reports of piracy incidents involving Australian vessels to the International Maritime Organisation, which has the situation under review by its maritime safety committee.

AMSA also issued a marine notice late last year warning ships of increased piracy activity in the South East Asian region and urging them to take increased security measures, including maintaining a reasonable speed, keeping decks floodlit and ensuring a good watch on deck. This problem needs to be addressed at the international and regional levels to ensure the security of our international shipping routes is maintained. Australia already is taking an active role in the International Maritime Organisation and AMSA will strongly support any measures for improved regional cooperation. AMSA is in contact with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to investigate possible courses of action on the diplomatic front about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Is Mr Greg McClelland, the Austrade manager for export incentives, correct when he says that the commercial history of applicants is not considered by Austrade when approving grants for export incentive schemes? If so, why is the business character of a claimant or the historical or ongoing viability of his or her company excluded from the criteria for approving grants? Does the Minister consider that the ongoing viability of a business or company is an appropriate additional criterion? Should the public expect that government funds made available for business purposes be subject to rigorous scrutiny as to public benefit before applications are approved? Finally, is there a need for a review of the scheme in the light of recent events?

—I think the important thing to appreciate about the EMDG scheme is that it is not a qualitative discretionary scheme requiring judgment or assessment of the merits of each particular claim or the commercial entity making the claim at the time it is made. Rather, it is what is described as a quantitative evidentiary scheme characterised by inspection of each claim for `permissible export activity' as that is defined under the Act. In other words, it is just the particular activity on which the expenditure is incurred that is, under the scheme of the Act, subject to scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: That means that the Act can be administered on a far more mechanical basis and far less administratively intense basis than would be the case if there were some evaluation of the value of the particular activity which is being sought to be financially assisted or if there were also some scrutiny to be made of the commercial worth or viability of the particular company in question. That has been the traditional rationale for the scheme being constructed in the way that it has been, and that has been fully debated in this Parliament, and it seems to have been accepted on that basis.

Moreover, I am told that the administration of the scheme and the way in which the relevant legislation has been drafted are designed to ensure protection against manipulation of the scheme by claimants reorganising their business affairs to obtain undue benefits. Each claim is investigated against the particular qualifying provisions. Section 19 of the Act prevents setting up new business entities to avoid the limiting provisions of the legislation such as the eight-year cut off; and there are other provisions designed to ensure that the maximum grant entitlement of $250,000 is properly administered and applied. From all those mechanical points of view, the Act falls into place and the legislative criteria have their separate role.

I suppose the question that does arise and certainly arises with me—and I have asked departmental officers, and certainly Mr Kerin, to have a further look at this today—is whether it is appropriate for taxpayers' money to be paid out to a company which is in receivership or liquidation at the time that the payment is made since, on a prima facie view of the matter, such a company is highly unlikely to be contributing much by way of continuing export value. So it seems to me to be a perfectly reasonable question.

As the Act now stands, such a payment has to be made and it is part of the money that can be taken into account by creditors and so on, as there is a statutory obligation to pay it. But that is a reasonable question. I am told that there is quite a complex policy judgment involved in this and it really needs a bit of thinking through. If a company is in receivership, for example, it means that it is still trading and trying to trade out of its difficulties. This kind of government grant can be extremely useful under those circumstances in keeping its viability intact and its capacity to contribute to Australia's export performance alive.

Similarly, even a company in liquidation may have particular bits of it that are continuing to trade successfully or have that capacity, and again it is not to be assumed, simply because the company itself is in liquidation, that the activity involved will necessarily cease or that the money that would be paid out would necessarily be lost to the Australian taxpayer. All of these things have to be taken into account and will be taken into account in the light of some of the issues thrown up by this case, but for the moment that is the way it works.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Pushing aside all the words, am I to take it from the Minister's reply that he is minded to take into account by way of some amendment, if it is possible, that the ongoing commercial viability of companies would be a reasonable criterion to write into this legislation?

—It is a reasonable criterion if we are prepared to spend a very great deal more than we are spending at the moment on the administration of the Act and slow down to a very much greater extent than is done at the moment the payment of accounts under it. It is a matter for policy judgment as to whether either of those two things are worth pursuing. But that is something that I will refer to Mr Kerin and the Department to have a further look at.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it a fact that, unbeknown to the Department of Foreign Affairs or the then Australian Ambassador to China, Dr Ross Garnaut, in 1987 Senator Richardson visited China and acted as an intermediary for Multiplex and Kumagai Gumi in relation to a joint venture involving the building of steel works, a port and an airport in southern China? PARA.TAB: I have seen a report in the Age that Australia's then ambassador, Dr Garnaut, had no knowledge of the visit until he heard about it from a Chinese official and that he, Dr Garnaut, contacted the Prime Minister about this. It might have usefully done so had Senator Richardson advised the Department or the Embassy about it. He did not, and that is really the end of the matter. That happens all the time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The Australian Police Ministers Council recently met to consider, amongst other things, steps to deal with domestic violence and the protection of victims of such violence. What was agreed at that meeting? If there were many changes, when will they be implemented?

—The police Ministers meeting in Melbourne on Friday considered various matters to do with the plight of, particularly, women in our society who are subjected to what is euphemistically called domestic violence but which is nothing less than criminal assault, usually in the sanctity of the home. Whilst the courts might intervene in the home town or city of the person concerned, by perhaps giving a restraining order or attempting to prevent the violent person further contacting the person who has been assaulted, quite often the person who has been assaulted will seek refuge in some other State.

PARA.TAB: For example, a woman who has received a protection order from the Cairns Magistrates Court may leave Cairns for Hobart, seeking safe haven or refuge there. She may fear that she might be pursued by the person who was subject to the protection order in Cairns in the Queensland jurisdiction. The police Ministers said on Friday that those sorts of orders ought to be portable and able to be transferred between jurisdictions.

In my example, the woman arriving in Hobart would register the order with the Hobart Magistrates Court and that order would become enforceable. The protection therefore given by the police in Cairns would be afforded to that woman in Hobart. That seems to me to be a very sensible and long overdue arrangement. I understand that the Attorneys-General, meeting in a week or so, will be deciding a draft Bill to implement that arrangement in all jurisdictions. I understand that South Australia has already introduced a Bill which enables that to occur.

In addition, it has also been decided that in those cases where police arrive at a scene of domestic violence and find that firearms are in the household, in the possession of the violent person or even just secreted away in the household, those firearms ought to be removed and confiscated and the person, during the currency of any restraint order, should not have those firearms returned, and that at the end of the duration of the restraint order that person ought to be subject to the need to apply for a licence in order to secure access to these firearms or weapons in the future. There would be a most stringent examination of the suitability of the person to have that licence renewed.

These are important moves in favour of ensuring that women, in particular, in our society who are subjected to intimidation, harassment or violence are given the protection to which they are entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister suggested that a woman arriving in Tasmania, for example, would advise a magistrate's court that there was an order for restraint against a certain person. Does the Minister judge that the woman arriving in Tasmania, fleeing from a violent person, would be the best person to make that application or does the Minister's proposal also provide an alternative way in which that protection can be guaranteed to such a victim?

—It is considered that when a jurisdiction is sought as a refuge or safe haven by a person who has been attacked or subject to some violent incident, it is best for that person to inform the court of the situation on arrival. It may be that a simple visit to a local police station would be a way in which that message could be conveyed to the magistrate's court in the jurisdiction of refuge. I believe that we perhaps need to look at trying to assist the woman concerned in order to make it as easy as possible for her to get the protection in all parts of Australia that she might visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Australian shipbuilders are increasingly successful in export markets but in many markets they face competition from foreign shipbuilders whose governments back them with competitive financing deals for the buying of ships. Does the Australian Government have a role in fostering competitive financing arrangements for the Australian industry?

—I would hope that the Government could help with that, but not directly as a government. There has been significant restructuring of the shipbuilding industry in Australia. That was done by more focused bounty arrangements, R&D grants, tax concessions, export marketing and training support. In 1982-83 exports of ships totalled $20m, and $5m in the second year. This year exports of ships will account for well over $200m. That has been so for several years. Australia has developed niche markets in a number of types of ships, particularly high speed ferries and luxury cruisers. It now accounts for 10 per cent of the world market in those classes of ships. Some Australian shipbuilders have orders until the turn of the century. As a result of that, shipbuilders are investing in more modern plant, undertaking further R&D and employing more skilled workers.

PARA.TAB: The question of competitive finance remains one of critical importance in export markets. To date, the Export and Finance Insurance Corporation, EFIC, has been a major source of export financing but the capacity to assist this one sector is limited, particularly in circumstances where buyer demand is enormous. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, along with EFIC and a number of leading legal and financial firms, has therefore organised a conference on ship financing which will take place in Sydney this week. The conference will look at some of the more innovative financing arrangements now being used in other markets to see whether they can be used here. This industry is already a success story and there is potential for greater success if the likely growth of demand in Asia and Europe is realised, as we believe it will be. This industry can contribute very much to supplying demand in those markets.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. What part does the Australian Government expect to play at next week's Earth Summit? In particular, will Australia be a signatory to Agenda 21?

—The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided me with an answer to this question which Senator Zakharov gave notice of. It is rather long. In order to assist the Opposition to ask some telling questions—which to this point it has not—I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Much work has been done in the international arena to address various environmental and development issues. However a better approach is needed if issues concerning the fundamental environment/development interface and the provision of essential needs to the world's population are to be addressed. The 1988 report of the world commission on environment and development promoted the concept of sustainable development as the means by which this could be done. The problems cannot be solved unilaterally or without the full co-operation of both developed and developing nations. There is an emerging international community and political will to accept sustainable development as the basis for future global development.

UNCED was established by United Nations Resolution 44/228 to discuss global adoption of sustainable development. The resolution lists nine sectors of global concern to be addressed (attachment). It is expected that UNCED will result in several declaratory documents and conventions (attached) and help resolve issues concerning technology transfer, financial resources, and the institutional arrangements needed to adopt sustainable development globally.

Australia contributed to the effectiveness of UNCED through active participation in preparatory committees (PREPCOM). The Ambassador for the Environment, Sir Ninian Stephen, lead the Australian delegation, and consulted with the NGO sector. Responsibility for UNCED preparations is shared by my Department (DASET) and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Policy is developed through an interdepartmental committee on international environment issues.

I (Mrs Kelly) will lead the Australian delegation. My colleagues the Minister for Resources and the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development will support me. Members of the delegation will be drawn from Commonwealth, State and local governments, Environment, Development and Industry non government organisations and the ACTU.

The Australian delegation is authorised to participate in the adoption of both the Rio Declaration and Agenda 21, on the understanding that they will be implemented in accordance with Australia's domestic economic interests and international priorities for sustainable development.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs been drawn to the suggestion contained in the Opposition's Fightback package that the Institute of Criminology be disbanded on the claimed grounds that it is duplicating services already provided by police and other crime agencies? How does the Government view this suggestion? Are there cogent reasons for the continued existence of the Institute?

—Mr President, I am aware that the Australian Institute of Criminology—which is Australia's only national crime research organisation—has been targeted for abolition by the Opposition in its Fightback package. I must say that the stated reason for its abolition just does not bear any scrutiny at all.

PARA.TAB: I have to indicate that perhaps two or three years ago the Australian Police Ministers Council was sceptical of or had some misgivings about the worth of the Australian Institute of Criminology. But there is no doubt that under the chairmanship of Professor Duncan Chappell the Institute has proved its worth as an adviser to governments and law enforcement organisations throughout Australia—and, indeed, even overseas—in a way which leads one to say that its practical advice, the papers it produces, the information it compiles, the way in which it analyses trends in criminal activity in Australia, and the preventative crime measures that it advises on have all been of great worth to law enforcement agencies throughout Australia. Indeed, the various police forces around Australia are amongst the best customers of the Institute's advice and assistance.

The practical character of the advice received is, I think, what makes it particularly attractive to those who actually have to operate within the criminal justice system. The prime example that I am aware of is the activity of the Institute in relation to the National Committee on Violence. It provided the Chair for that very important committee and the various support and secretariat personnel and activity underpinning the work of that National Committee on Violence which has led to the active implementation throughout Australia of very practical measures aimed at reducing the culture of violence in our society. Certainly, the Institute has had a very crucial and central role in the devising and implementation of those measures. Not only government agencies but also the NRMA, the Australian Bankers Association and others have asked for work to be done by the Institute and have been most satisfied with the work that has been undertaken.

The Institute is a particularly cost effective organisation. In a criminal justice system in which the costs would certainly exceed $3 billion annually, the cost of the Institute is the equivalent to the annual cost of keeping 12 police cars staffed by two police officers on the road for 24 hours per day. Perhaps another equivalent would be the construction of 40 police or prison cells. The opportunity for cost savings within the criminal justice system by abolishing the Institute are not there. The abolition of this Institute would remove a very good source of practical advice for those who have to operate within the criminal justice system in this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I preface my question by saying that Australia has the largest magnesite deposits in the world near Gladstone. What is the Government doing to maximise the return to Australia of the Gladstone deposit and to ensure that Australia plays a significant role in the emerging magnesite metal industry?
—This is desperate stuff.

—Senator Alston, in the usual open-mouthed policy which he adopts, says this is desperate stuff. As a matter of fact, it is very important stuff and the answer is more important to a diligent questioner like the honourable senator who asked this question than many of the questions being directed today. Magnesium is of course a very strong and light metal—lighter than aluminium. Demand for the metal will come especially from the motor vehicle industry as part of its efforts to manufacture lighter and more efficient cars. For example, the Japanese motor vehicle industry projections for the use of magnesium by that industry over the next decade go up in a very steep curve.

PARA.TAB: I will answer this question in great length because it will relieve Opposition members of some embarrassment about the growing horror of nothing to think about which they confront. It has been pathetic. The main barrier to realising this technology is the development of a refining process that will produce very high levels of purity in the metal and, of course, it has to be cost efficient. Research by CSIRO has made this prospect feasible and the next step will be a $50m pilot plant based in Gladstone in Queensland which will be funded by the Commonwealth and Queensland governments contributing 50 per cent of the plant's cost and Queensland Metals, CSIRO, Mount Isa Mines Holdings and the Japanese firm Ube contributing the remaining 50 per cent. Over the next four years there will be intensive research and development that should lead, at the end of that period, to a bankable feasibility study and thereafter to a world scale magnesium metal plant. The advantage of that for Australia is enormous in light of the very pure and extensive deposit of magnesium ore which this country has. In addition to the very high returns from magnesium metal in terms of value-adding down the chain, this plant can lead to the establishment in Australia of significant downstream industries, just as occurred in previous decades with the aluminium industry. So this is an important question and we look forward to monitoring progress on this important development in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I address my question to you. It relates to your letter to the Congressional Liaison Officer in the Australian Embassy in Washington, Mr Chris Lamb, in which you stated:

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Hill, the information that was contained in my letter to the Congressional Liaison Officer in Washington was based upon information given to me and my senior adviser by Mr Symons. When he spoke to my senior adviser the next day he provided information which then formed the basis of the letter to Mr Lamb. With the benefit of hindsight, I probably would have worded a sentence in my letter differently.

PARA.TAB: I went to Mr Lamb because he is an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. By referring to him I was consulting with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. There was no contact made other than that with Mr Lamb. I did not contact congressmen or Congress officials. Lamb was suggested as the best person to refer to in this matter for two reasons. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Mr President, I take it from your answer that you confirm that you did not check the facts with either the Minister or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Do you in fact have anything in written form from Mr Symons that justifies your statement that President Kabua had sought the assistance of the Australian Government? With the greatest of respect, there is nothing in the documents which you have tabled or which the Prime Minister has made public that gives you the basis for reaching that assumption.
—In reply to Senator Hill, the advice I got from Mr Lamb and the advice that my assistant got from Mr Symons the next day was by telephone.
—Did you take notes?

—In reply to that interjection, I point out that when Mr Symons was in my office, he had a briefcase full of documents. I wish I had them all now, but I do not. The documents that I have are the documents that I tabled. I say to Senator Hill that against the background, in retrospect, I would have changed the wording of part of my letter. I would have said, `Against the background of the regional cooperation, Mr Symons advised me that President Kabua was, through him'—that is, Mr Symons—`seeking the assistance of the Australian Government'. I would not have used the words, `has sought'. I think I have said that in my report. I call Senator Jones—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Earlier in Question Time, you failed to call someone from the Opposition because you said he was not standing at the time. If you are going to wait for someone on that side to stand, why do you not wait for someone on this side to stand?

If it is a two-hour Question Time, the Democrats—
—That doesn't answer the question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the very strong statement from Washington on the conflict that has engulfed Bosnia-Herzegovina and other parts of former Yugoslavia, with Western governments now naming Serbia as the culprit? In view of the appalling violence against the citizens of Bosnia-Herzegovina, will the Minister impose sanctions against the republic of Serbia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only am I aware of Washington's strong statement on the matter, but also I was present in Lisbon a couple of days ago when James Baker made the first version of that statement. He subsequently added further material to what has already been a very strong position taken by the United States. The situation, certainly in Sarajevo and in other areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina, is now critical. The Yugoslav National Army is refusing to complete its withdrawal. Shelling, sniper fire and widespread fighting continue. The food situation is particularly serious. Hunger related deaths are beginning to be reported in Sarajevo. Medical supplies in Sarajevo have been exhausted. Six thousand pregnant women and newborn babies are without medicine. Thirty-five thousand diabetics, as Jim Baker said and as reported this morning, are without insulin. Serbian forces control Sarajevo airport which remains closed.

PARA.TAB: At the Lisbon conference I attended on the weekend, I joined with other foreign Ministers represented there in calling on the parties to exercise maximum restraint and warning those responsible for the continuation of violence and disrespect for human rights that they would be held responsible before the international community. Observers agree that all the principal groups do share some responsibility for this tragedy, but it is also generally agreed that the greatest responsibility has to be attributed to the Yugoslav National Army and its allies which are pursuing Serbian interests.
The Government already has economic measures in place against the republic of Serbia, if it can now be so described, which

ANSWER.PARA: is excluded from our program of assistance for eastern Europe and which is being denied the benefit of the Australian system of tariff preferences. The size of the Australian Embassy in Belgrade has been severely reduced. May I say now that, when the Australian Ambassador leaves this week at the natural conclusion of his posting, he will not be replaced, as yet another indication of our displeasure with the authorities in Belgrade.

PARA.TAB: Two of the former Yugoslavia's three consulates in Australia will close down by the end of May according to the authorities in Belgrade. We are consulting with other countries on what further steps could now be taken. I have just asked the Australian delegation to the UN to add its voice to the growing call for mandatory international sanctions against Serbia. Australia would, of course, immediately implement such sanctions. The question does arise of other forms of UN action under chapter 7 of the UN charter. That is now being actively discussed and I will do my best to keep Parliament informed of what is happening in that respect. I say, finally, that in view of the tragic humanitarian situation, Australia will be donating a further $100,000 to the UN appeal, bringing our contribution so far to $550,000.

—In reply to the interjection, I do not think I had seen Mr Symons for at least 12 years. I was free at the time, so I agreed. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister and the Senate itself to recall a question I asked the former Minister on 6 May regarding AOTC's plans to shed 20,000 jobs over the next five years, 5,000 of those immediately; and what the Government intended to do to replace those jobs—jobs lost because of the Government's policy of deregulation of Australian telecommunications. TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. It is an issue of great concern—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—On your side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, obviously there is no interest by those opposite in other questions being asked in this place.
—Order! Senator Reynolds, please ask the question.

—The Minister will be concerned about the incident regarding two commercial aircraft carrying 150 passengers coming close to a mid-air collision over Cairns last week. Can the Minister assure the Senate that this incident is in no way linked to earlier problems with new radar installations in Cairns and is now the subject of standard thorough investigation?

—Yes, I can give that assurance to the Senate. The incident at Cairns, which involved a breakdown in separation between two commercial aircraft, is currently being invested by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. I will provide a report on that investigation as soon as it is made available to me. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has already made it public that this incident, which involved a breakdown of separation, did not in any way involve the air traffic control system at Cairns. I will not indicate at this stage that there was a possibility of a mid-air collision. I am not sure, and I will not be sure until the investigation is completed, as to how close the aircraft were. What clearly happened was a breakdown of separation in the distance between the two aircraft.

PARA.TAB: I advise the Senate that in respect of the radar at Cairns, as a result of the installation of the recording equipment at the Cairns tower—which I was able to visit recently, discussing this matter with both the technicians and the controllers—and the successful capturing of one of these incidents electronically on tape, the matter is well on the way to being corrected. New software has been developed as the result of the analysis of the data on that tape. That software has been extensively tested at a tower. To this point it appears that the problem was corrected.

The advice I received from the controllers and the technicians was that they were absolutely confident that this software glitch would be corrected. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Access to Taxation Records by Inquiries

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Coulter asked me a question about the access of the Western Australian royal commission to tax files. I am able to provide the honourable senator with some further information at this stage. On 15 May the Prime Minister announced that the Government proposed to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to put beyond doubt the right of access by the Western Australia royal commission—and, incidentally, other royal commissions—to certain information held by the Australian Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the official advice to the Government from the Tax Office was that the Western Australian royal commission could gain the necessary access to tax information by way of the process established by the insertion of section 3E in the Act in 1989. Section 3E was introduced after the Fitzgerald Royal Commission and was designed precisely to provide controlled access to tax information by law enforcement agencies. The provisions of section 3E have been utilised by a variety of agencies including, for example, the Western Australian police force.

The Government has decided, however, to specifically include within the ambit of section 3E royal commissions in order to remove any doubt or lack of clarity on this matter and, of course, to avoid involving the tax administration in cheap political controversy. It was pertinent to this decision that, despite an express invitation by tax officials to officers of the Western Australian royal commission at the outset to utilise the avenue provided by section 3E, the Royal Commission's officers had reservations about this avenue and declined to use it.

The amendments to be introduced, I believe today in the House of Representatives, will remove any such reservations, whether or not they are soundly based, and will specifically extend to the Western Australian Royal Commission and other royal commissions prescribed by regulation access to relevant tax information provided for in the provisions of section 3E. They will also allow the Western Australian Royal Commission to disclose the information in a confidential report to the State Governor, and they will allow the Governor to disclose that information to a law enforcement authority and permit the Western Australian Royal Commission to disclose the information to certain persons in private proceedings. The amendments were drafted following consultations with the Western Australian Royal Commission which has advised that they are satisfactory for the purposes of the Commission. All that remains is for the amendments to have timely unimpeded passage through the legislative process.

I recall Senator Coulter also asking me how many tax files or matters were referred to the Fitzgerald Royal Commission. I do not have an answer on that yet, but I will obtain that for him as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan previously gave notice that he would move a motion. However, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement, and expresses its grave concern that the President of the Senate failed to exercise due care in requesting the Australian Embassy in Washington to assist Mr Symons and as a result made false assertions in his request, thus compromising the office of the President of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, we regard this matter extremely seriously. We do so because of your position, your high office and your responsibility—not to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, or someone else, as might be the case, on the other side of the chamber, but to this Senate, to this institution. We expect of you, and we are justified in expecting of you, the highest standards and we expect that, certainly, in the carrying out of your functions, you will exercise all reasonable care.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, in this instance when you took it upon yourself to write this request to our Embassy in Washington that help be given to this businessman, Mr Symons, a request that apparently seems to have been made at the beck of Senator Richardson, the then Minister for Social Security, you failed to exercise that due care. Mr President, I note that you sigh, but today you have confirmed what you said previously: that Senator Richardson brought Symons around to you, and the purpose for which he did that was in order that you might facilitate for the benefit of Symons your contacts within the United States. You took it upon yourself to do that by making contact direct with our Embassy in Washington and, in particular, with the Congressional Liaison Officer, Mr Lamb, and you determined to do that by letter.

Mr President, I do not quarrel with you in fact deciding to assist him. I do not even quarrel with the fact that you decided to do that by making contact with our embassy in Washington direct. What I quarrel with is, first, that you did it in the form of a letter that now has been demonstrated to be factually incorrect; and, secondly, that you should have realised the assertions that were being made by Symons were such that any prudent senator, let alone the President of the Senate, would check out the facts before he put his name to that letter. That was your failure in this instance.

Mr President, you asserted in this letter that the President of the Marshall Islands had asked Australia for its assistance in this matter, and you signed a letter to that effect without having before you any material upon which you could reasonably come to that conclusion. When you made documents public at the request of the Prime Minister, you made public a series of documents that had been provided by Mr Symons. Those documents certainly tended to indicate that he had some status that had apparently been given to him by the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands.

There was nothing in those documents that supported the claim by Symons that the President of the Marshall Islands had asked the Australian Government for its assistance. That is why we say that, at the very least, any reasonable senator would have picked up the phone and checked with the Department to see whether that was the case before putting that in writing and sending off such a letter to America.

In your instance, Mr President, because of your position I would have thought that you would have probably checked it with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade as well, but you did neither. You did not check with the Department or with the Minister. It is even more incredible when the officer from your staff assisting you in this matter is in fact an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs. That demonstrates even more to me that you would have been put on warning to exercise that care by simply doing a check. However, you did not and you made certain assertions which have turned out to be false.

Mr President, when you wrote that letter to America you did not advise the Department then that you had sent the letter; you did not advise the Minister that you had sent the letter; and the total picture—almost as you have conceded when answering questions in the Senate today—was that you acted without due care. You have said that you regret that you took Symons at face value, and I acknowledge that concession. I suspect that you were influenced as much by the documents that he had in his possession as you were by the fact that a senior Minister in the Government, Senator Richardson, brought him around to you seeking assistance in this matter. Whatever it was—whether it was on the basis of the documents that Symons presented to you or for some other reason—there is certainly no reason that you have put before the Senate that would have justified you writing in such terms. To write in such terms could have in fact caused embarrassment to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has.

—Yes, it has. In due course what has occurred has certainly been embarrassing to this country and it is highly unfortunate that you allowed yourself to become enmeshed in this matter, Mr President. Naturally, you would say that with the benefit of hindsight, now that we know more about Symons and his business practices. Nevertheless, even without the benefit of hindsight, you should have been put on warning to do those checks.

PARA.TAB: I cannot imagine any senator writing that letter without checking first with the Department that in fact it is the case. It is such an astonishing assertion that the president of another country had asked the Australian Government for assistance, and thus this person Symons turns up on the President of the Senate's doorstep asking that a letter be written to our Embassy in the United States.

It is true that Senator Sibraa apparently knew Symons from the Young Labor movement some years before and perhaps in some way the fact that he knew of Symons and his background, plus the fact that he had been brought around to him by Senator Richardson—the senior power broker within the President's faction—gave the President greater comfort. However, Mr President, you certainly should have learnt from subsequent events that such comfort was falsely placed.

The situation is that your act has compromised your position as President of the Senate and that is something that we on this side of the chamber regard gravely. In fact, we would be tempted to go further. We are on the public record as saying that, if you are going to act without exercising such due care, you will not continue to hold the confidence of this side of the chamber. However, the Australian Democrats, for some reason that we are yet to totally understand—and we will hear the argument from Senator Coulter today—are prepared to excuse that lack of due care in some way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called fairness.

—I do not think it is a question of fairness. It is a question of the exercise of due care. I do not think that Senator Aulich would have written that letter without checking first with the Department. Why should the President of the Senate do so and thus put himself in a position whereby his acts can compromise the position of the President of this institution? That is our criticism and I put it to the chamber that it is a very valid criticism. At the very least the Senate should be prepared to pass the motion that I moved today. I commend that motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —When looking at the two situations, the one in relation to Senator Richardson, a former Minister, and the one in relation to yourself, Mr President, the Democrats have imagined ourselves in precisely the same positions and asked the question, `What would we have done under the circumstances?'.

PARA.TAB: It seemed to me that if, as you have explained, a senior Minister came into my office, introduced somebody to me, said something like, `I have known this man for 25 years. He is related to me by marriage. Would you help with his introduction in the United States?' and then left the room, and, as a consequence of that, I was then shown a number of documents—some of which have been circulated to us—on the letterhead of Ministers from a foreign government and was orally given other information which was consistent with that information, I think I would have done exactly the same as you did, Mr President, and I would have written such a letter.

If all honourable senators examine their own consciences and background, each one of us would remember that, given those sorts of circumstances, we have provided references for people without going back and checking. If there was no such corroboration, certainly any reasonable person would have checked and sought corroboration of the evidence before him. With the exception of stating the matter in relation to President Kabua as a fact, as you have already indicated, it would have been far more prudent to have said, `I am informed by Mr Symons that', or words to that effect. But, with that exception, it certainly seems to us that, given that set of circumstances, there was no reason why you should have sought corroboration of that documentation and the oral information that Mr Symons evidently gave you. If one were to seek to check every document, phone call or introduction that comes across one's desk or through one's office, it seems to me that we would not do any work at all. I believe that any reasonable senator, given those circumstances, would have behaved exactly as you behaved, Mr President.

Of course, the Democrats came to a very different conclusion in relation to Senator Richardson who was the instigator of that introduction, of course, and was the one who had issued the reference for Mr Symons. He had not only issued a letter of introduction but also a reference knowing full well that Mr Symons was to set up a $40m company in a foreign country. It seems to me that, whether one takes the protestations of ignorance from Senator Richardson at their face value or whether one believes that he had more knowledge than he is admitting to in relation to Mr Symons and his previous business dealings—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Are the matters to which Senator Coulter is now referring relevant to the question that is currently before the chair? Also, is it proper to be raising these issues about the credibility of another honourable senator when he is not here and there is no motion before the chamber in respect of that honourable senator?
—I will allow Senator Coulter to continue on the basis that he is explaining why he took a different attitude to Senator Richardson than he did to me.

—Thank you, Mr President. I think it is relevant. I was asked on many occasions last week about the differentiation which the Democrats made between Senator Richardson's behaviour and your behaviour in this case. I have described your actions as those of an innocent victim. I believe that Senator Richardson's part in this is very much relevant to the action that you took. In his speech, Senator Hill invited me to explain why we drew that distinction.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, it seemed to me that whether one believed that Senator Richardson had more knowledge than he was admitting to or that he was as ignorant as he claimed, either way his behaviour was not acceptable for a Minister. Consequently, even before his statement went to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and was released publicly, we were saying that it would be extremely difficult to imagine the circumstance contained in his explanation which would adequately explain why he issued the reference and then later interceded with the President of the Marshall Islands on Mr Symons's behalf. Those are the bases upon which we drew that distinction.

In relation to your action, Mr President, I think, if anything, it indicates a greater complicity on the part of Senator Richardson rather than any misdemeanour or lack of care on your part. In conclusion, I repeat that if we each put ourselves in the situation in which you found yourself and ask ourselves whether we would not have written such a letter, I believe we must honestly say that, given those circumstances, we would have done exactly as you did.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on this matter. Senator Coulter has made what one might describe as a `there but for the grace of God go I' sort of speech. I do not propose to do that. Senator Sibraa, as President of the Senate, has given an absolutely frank and full explanation of his quite peripheral involvement with Mr Symons.
—How do you know?
—`Open Mouth' again asks how do I know. That is my judgment. I may be wrong, but I am entitled to make it.
—In your view.
—Yes, that is what I said.
—You made a statement.
—`Open Mouth' should read the transcript in the silence of his room.

PARA.TAB: The facts are quite straightforward and they are on the record. Senator Richardson introduced Mr Symons to Senator Sibraa. Mr Symons produced a number of documents purporting to show that he had the authority to negotiate on behalf of the Marshall Islands Government. Mr Symons said that he had no contacts in Washington and wanted to contact officials or congressmen with expertise on specific matters.

A member of Senator Sibraa's staff who was present suggested that Mr Symons should speak to Mr Chris Lamb, a congressional liaison officer in Australia's embassy in Washington—of course, an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with whom Senator Sibraa's office had had, as I understand it, long and quite frequent contact. That was the step which the President of the Senate took to involve the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the bureaucracy in this matter. The staff member spoke to Mr Lamb about this in a telephone call which he made to Washington. Senator Sibraa then wrote to Mr Lamb, and a copy of his letter is on the public record.

Senator Sibraa, the President, has said two things about this matter. He has said that, with the wisdom of hindsight, his letter could have been worded more carefully. I agree with him about that—I think it could have been worded more carefully. But in a situation in which one is writing a letter offering an introduction to somebody overseas, as I understand the President of the Senate does and Ministers in this Government do, I would have thought the matter of precise wording is not something which at the time would be paramount in one's mind. Senator Sibraa has already said that it could have been worded more carefully. In the course of answering questions today he has also said that he regrets that he took Mr Symons at face value.

However, the fact remains that the only assistance the President provided to Mr Symons was to refer him to an Australian Government official in Washington. All this talk about damage to the image of the Australian Government and damage to Australia as a result of some activities of Mr Symons and so on just does not take account of that simple fact. The President referred him to an Australian Government Foreign Affairs official in Washington.

Attempts to pursue Senator Sibraa in this issue are futile. No serious allegation has been made against him. This whole thing has been something of a fizzer, a Guy Fawkes night performance. A wick has been lit and the whole thing has fizzled out, despite all the illumination which the Opposition has tried to cast on the matter.
