We will not be supporting Senator Hill's motion and the sooner the Opposition and the Senate accept that the better. This matter can then be resolved. We regret the time that has been taken—it could have been used for more important business—and the historic precedent of a two-hour Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not historic at all!
—I said, `hysteric'.
—Supercilious grin.
—Senator Newman says, `Supercilious grin'. I often grin superciliously at her. We regret the time spent debating all this; we had two hours of going nowhere.
—That is what you said last week about Senator Richardson.
—No, it is not. We want this matter dealt with as expeditiously as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it very disappointing that the Government can respond in the way that it has. Those of us who have taken an interest in this matter will recall the sorts of dismissive comments made by people such as the President of the ALP, who somehow pretended that a censure motion was of no consequence. Indeed, he felt that one was not doing one's job unless one was censured on a regular basis.

PARA.TAB: At no time has this Government taken this issue seriously. It is sheer hypocrisy to come along now and pretend that somehow it is a waste of the Senate's valuable time, and that we ought to be back talking about record levels of unemployment, very low levels of productivity and all those wonderful achievements that the Government is so proud of!

The matter that really concerns us is the statement that you, Mr President, have tabled today and the questions which still remain very much unanswered. I am concerned in particular—and the Senate should also be concerned—about the conclusion to your statement, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: As the matters I have set out make clear, it was not possible for me to report to the Senate earlier.

As you make clear in the earlier part of your statement, you were in a position from 8 May onwards to know that the letter from you to Mr Lamb had been located, and you obtained a copy of that letter the following day. It is not at all clear—you have certainly not explained it in this statement—why you were not able to clarify that situation and put to rest any misunderstanding that might have been in the public mind by making a public statement. You choose to shelter behind the words:
It was then clear to me that . . . I should make a statement to the Senate on the matter on the next day of sitting.

I do not understand for a moment why that should be. You were quite happy to provide material to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which you knew would be used by him in the public arena and well prior to any resumption of the Parliament, and to ensure that Senator Richardson got his just desserts. When it suited the Prime Minister and yourself, that material was made available for use in the public arena. So there was nothing to stop you clarifying this matter prior to the resumption of the Senate. Yet you chose to do nothing in that intervening period. It may well be that if the Prime Minister had not pre-empted matters, you may not have ever raised the matter again. It is certainly now possible for you to say that that was always your intention; but it certainly does not follow that that was going to happen when you have not explained why you were not prepared to make that statement in public as soon as the matters came to your attention.

PARA.TAB: It is also unsatisfactory for you to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The two questions which were asked . . . caused me to recall that I had met Mr Symons last year . . .

You do not go on to say that you had known Mr Symons quite well some years ago. Whilst you may not have seen him in the last 12 years, it was certainly a name that should have sprung to mind. Indeed, he was not just another individual; he was someone who was wheeled in by one of the heavies of the Right with implicit, if not explicit, instructions for you to do the right thing by him.

PARA.TAB: It seems extraordinary that you, Mr President, should again seek to shelter behind the proposition that somehow this sort of reference was something that people do all the time, that therefore it was of no particular consequence to you and no bells were rung. I think it would be very helpful in trying to assess the merits of those assertions to look at the volume of references that you provide and the basis on which they are provided. I find it extraordinary that you can have someone wheeled in in this matter and, on the basis of something that was said to you, make a statement which you now concede was quite untrue. You say that your fault was in taking Symons at face value. It might have been more accurate to say that your problem lay in taking Senator Richardson at face value. But, nonetheless, where is the material that demonstrates that you proceeded to have this reference put together on the basis of what was told to you by Symons? Is there not a note of the conversation with Symons taken by your advisers at the time? I would not expect you to be taking notes of the discussion. But one would have thought that if they are sitting in on the meeting, they would take notes.

The subsequent follow-up discussion between your senior adviser, Mr Peppinck, and Mr Symons also, one would have thought, would have found its way into written notes, which would again corroborate your now assertion that this false statement was based on matters told to you or your advisers. Where is the evidence to support that? If it is not forthcoming, it suggests that this was really put together on the basis of someone's recollection of what Symons might have said when he was wheeled in. It does not make any difference at all to the state of affairs to claim that somehow he came in with a box of papers which were quite impressive. They are of no use to you when it comes to putting a reference together. You have certain papers that are left with you. They in no way support the contention that the President of the Marshall Islands had sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions. The proper place to verify that would have been through our own Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

At the very least, one would have thought that in putting this reference together someone would either have located information from Symons that was in concrete form or taken a note of what he said over the phone at the time. If neither exists, it simply suggests that somehow you were quite prepared to just put a few words together, careless of the consequences.
I also find it strange that the letter to Mr Lamb says:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that you have already spoken with Greg Symons . . .

Mr Lamb makes it clear, subsequently, that he does not have any such recollection. He says that subsequent to this undated letter, which he believes arrived with him on about 22 November, he rang Mr Peppinck. But you go on to say:
. . . who as you know, is an adviser to the President of the Republic . . .

The words `as you know' suggest that Mr Lamb had previously been put in the picture about Symons. In other words, prior to that letter being written, someone had been in contact with Mr Lamb. Either it was you in person or it was your adviser. But, in any event, and particularly in view of the fact that the matters were followed up by Mr Peppinck in phone calls to Washington—one would assume that that is not an everyday occurrence—it seems extraordinary that you can dismiss Symons as simply a name that did not ring any bells until much later in the piece.

PARA.TAB: One would have thought that you, Mr President, only had to be half awake in this chamber to have very much recognised the name `Symons' and to have been very much aware of precisely what had happened, rather than saying that you were merely prompted to recall that you may have done something to put Symons in contact with the Australian Embassy. That seems to me to suggest that you knew precisely what you had done in relation to Symons and you also knew that you needed to put inquiries in train, which you did. You say it was due to pressure of business. It was not clear what that business was or why it should have taken priority over the prospect that you may have cause to make a very early explanation to Senator Evans, who had otherwise unwittingly misled the chamber. In all the circumstances, one would have thought that that was the highest political priority. Yet you did not do that. You simply allowed the letter to be finally provided to you on the following day and then sat back and did nothing over the period prior to the Prime Minister blowing Senator Richardson out of the water.

This is not just any ordinary reference; it is a glowing testimonial which one would find it very difficult to believe would be provided to the average ordinary citizen who might have been brought in, even by a senior Cabinet Minister. The irresistible inference has to be that because of Senator Richardson's unique status in the tribe, anything that anyone was prepared to say in support of their own case or reference, if they were brought in by Senator Richardson, was good enough for you. I would have thought that that is very much a breach of the duty of care that you owe to this chamber and, indeed, to the citizens of Australia when you are from your high office seeking to make representations on behalf of a person who has come to see you. As you would now concede, it caused you to mislead a senior official in the Australian Embassy.

In all those circumstances, it is simply not good enough for Senator Coulter to say, `Well, of course, if we were all put in the situation, we would all do the same thing'. The facts of the matter are that this was not just any ordinary low level citizen wanting a low grade piece of paper. This was someone who was in an extraordinary situation, brought in by a unique individual and asking you to make representations at the highest levels. In those circumstances, I think you need to explain in much greater detail why you said that somehow this was a routine matter and that it was not necessary for you to verify the very serious claims that were being made in that undated correspondence.

I would therefore support Senator Hill in his expression that you, Mr President, have failed to exercise due care in requesting the Embassy to assist Mr Symons, and as a result, false assertions have been made in the request. We do not believe that your explanation is satisfactory. We have tried to make it clear that if the Democrats take the issue of propriety as seriously as they should, they should have no option but to support our motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to defend you against the suggestion that your behaviour has been such that the Senate should properly pass a motion of this kind—one of grave concern. The nub of the attack, such as it is, that has been mounted by the Opposition is very simple and straightforward. As Senator Hill made clear, those opposite do not quarrel with you deciding to render assistance to this gentleman by way of a letter of introduction. They acknowledge that that is the kind of thing that any of us—and certainly someone in your position—might routinely be called upon to do. Moreover, they do not quarrel with you deciding to make direct contact with Mr Lamb in Washington as being an appropriate person through whom Australian Government assistance—if, in turn, it was appropriate—might be rendered. I certainly do not quarrel with either of those judgments that have been made by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: What the Opposition does quarrel with, as was made clear by Senator Hill and again by Senator Alston, is what they describe as a factually incorrect statement in your letter, and what was also described as a factually incorrect statement which you failed to check out. The statement in question is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . President Kabua has sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions in Washington. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not only that one; read the first paragraph.
—What else is Senator Walters troubled about?
—That is not what the debate was about.
—I will deal with that. The reference to Greg Symons who, as honourable senators know, is an adviser to the President, is simply—
—He is not an adviser to the President.

—I will come to that. The reference to `as honourable senators know' is clearly a reference to an earlier conversation between Mr Peppinck on Senator Sibraa's staff, and Mr Lamb in Washington, which took place on 13 May, as is fully documented in—
—On 13 May?
—On the thirteenth of the month in question—November. It is fully documented in Senator Sibraa's report which is now in the public domain.
—He is not an adviser to the President.

—I will come to that. It was an entirely reasonable judgment for Senator Sibraa to make on the basis of the documentation before him that Mr Symons was an adviser to the President of the Republic of the Marshall Islands.
—What documentation?

—I listened very carefully to what Senator Hill said; with the utmost respect, I am not going to listen nearly so carefully to what Senator Walters says because I think she has missed the point of the debate. It may or may not be the case that Mr Symons was an adviser to the President of the Republic of the Marshall Islands; that is something which is presently the subject of a court case in the Marshall Islands. Whether the authority that Mr Symons was holding out was real authority or feigned authority is a matter for the judgment of the courts.

PARA.TAB: What is not in doubt and what has not been challenged about Senator Sibraa's behaviour was that he was confronted with documentation which, on its face value, seemed to give Mr Symons that status. We have before us specifically a document purportedly signed by the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Marshall Islands, Mr Kijiner, conferring upon Mr Symons the status of a consultant to the Marshall Islands Government. We have a further description by Senator Sibraa of other documents having been shown to him which conferred upon Mr Symons the status of someone who was close to, representative of, an adviser to, a delegate of—use any of the words you like—the Marshall Islands Government.

There is plenty of evidence, on the information before the Senate, on which Senator Sibraa could reasonably have made the assumption that Mr Symons did have that status. I repeat that whether, in fact, he had that status is not a matter for us to make judgments about, that is a matter for the courts in the Marshall Islands and I certainly do not want to trespass on that.That is one thing about the situation which Senator Sibraa confronted which seems to be beyond doubt—Senator Sibraa was confronted with someone making a claim to that status which seemed, on the face of it, to be thoroughly reasonably based.

The second thing with which Senator Sibraa was confronted was that person, with that apparent status, making a request through Senator Sibraa for Australian Government assistance. Mr Symons made a request to the Australian Government for Australian Government assistance. Mr Symons made that request to Senator Sibraa to put him in touch with the appropriate representative of the Australian Government, namely, Mr Lamb. Mr Symons clearly made a request through Senator Sibraa of the Australian Government.

If we put those two facts together we have a situation where someone purporting to be a representative of, a delegate of, the Marshall Islands Government is making a request of the Australian Government. That is the explanation, if we are fair minded about it, of the particular contested sentence in Senator Sibraa's letter. I will repeat the relevant part of Senator Sibraa's letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . President Kabua has sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions in Washington. . .

What that letter should have said is, `President Kabua has, through Mr Symons,'—and I underline those last three words—`sought the assistance of the Australian Government in expediting discussions in Washington'. On my understanding of President Sibraa's explanation today, his explanation of what was done and the report he made to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), is why this language is used. There is an implicit phrase missing which would completely explain the context in which this letter was written. If Senator Sibraa had worded the letter more cautiously, as he acknowledges he should have, he would have said that President Kabua has, through Mr Symons, sought the assistance of the Australian Government.

PARA.TAB: If we read the letter in that way—fairly, and taking into account the situation that Senator Sibraa confronted—we will see that what Senator Sibraa made was not, on the face of it, an incorrect statement; not, on the face of it, a statement that should have been checked out with the Foreign Affairs Minister of the Marshall Islands or anyone else. It was simply an incomplete statement; a statement which failed to draw together all the particular linkages that were available to him. That is certainly the way I have read the statement subsequently; it is certainly the way in which I believe that Mr Lamb and the Ambassador in Pohnpei read it.

It is obviously the case that there was no form of communication with the Australian Government from the Marshall Islands other than through Mr Symons who was the purported representative of the Marshall Islands, but it is not obviously the case that Senator Sibraa should have taken steps more than he did to establish that state of affairs. I repeat, Senator Sibraa was confronted with two factual situations: firstly, someone standing in front of him, armed with a sheath of documentation purporting, on the face of it, totally credibly, to have the status as a full scale representative of the Marshall Islands Government; and, secondly, someone with that status asking him to get some assistance for the Marshall Islands from the Australian Government.

Senator Sibraa, or the person who drafted the letter on his behalf, simply put those two propositions together in an abbreviated fashion and said, `President Kabua has sought the assistance'. To spell it out clearly, he should have said, `President Kabua has, through Mr Symons, sought the assistance'. If those opposite read the letter in that way they will see that the problem that was generated by Senator Sibraa in writing this letter was not one based on any negligence on his part, and was not based on any error of judgment on his part; it was simply based on, essentially, a drafting infelicity, not spelling things out to the extent that he reasonably should have to avoid any possible doubt.

If those opposite are prepared, as Senator Coulter was, to read the letter in that way and understand the situation confronting Senator Sibraa, it should be perfectly apparent that there is no ground at all for expressing concern or censure. Senator Sibraa acted perfectly reasonably on the particular evidence with which he was confronted, on the basis of the apparent status of the person with which he was confronted. I do not honestly believe that any of us in a similar situation—certainly none of those opposite—would have behaved differently. For all those reasons, I believe that the Senate should reject this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the following motion moved earlier today by Senator Hill:

PARA.TAB: The Senate take note of the President's statement and expresses its grave concern that the President of the Senate failed to exercise due care in requesting the Australian Embassy in Washington to assist Mr Symons and as a result made false assertions in his request thus compromising the office of the President of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are seven regrettable aspects to this matter and I would like to deal with them one by one. The first is that the information now made available to this chamber was not made available to senators as quickly as it could have been and, in my view, as quickly as it should have been.

PARA.TAB: It is perfectly simple to send a memo or a written report to a Prime Minister or to any other Minister; it is just as simple to send that information to senators. I say that because, after all, the position that was used to facilitate Mr Symons's getting whatever he did get in the United States was really that of the President; it was not that of an ALP backbencher. My understanding is that the President of the Senate does not actually report to the Prime Minister. So I am amazed that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) received a report from the President of the Senate before senators did. I regret that that has happened.

My second regret about the matter concerns the factual errors themselves. I understand your position, Mr President. You say that you were provided with numerous documents—a whole box or bag of documents; a bag of tricks that someone was carting around—and you now wish that you had all of them in front of you. That may be the case. But from what you have told us today, the letter that you signed later in November was signed on the basis of nothing but your recollections, or the recollections of your staffer, Mr Peppinck, of verbal conversations with Mr Symons. Were that not the case, were there some documentation to support the assertions of fact in the letter which we now know are wrong, you would no doubt have produced those documents. But you do not have them. You have told us that, following your meeting, Mr Peppinck had some discussions with Mr Symons. No doubt, Mr Symons gave him the good snake oil on what ought to be put in the letter. You have either taken Mr Peppinck's word for it or Mr Peppinck has it wrong.

I do not accept Senator Evans's version of events that this is nothing other than infelicitous drafting. I think that is stretching the bounds of good faith somewhat. The fact is that there are factual errors in the document. They are there because you have signed the document on nothing but the recollections of your staffer's conversations with someone the day you left the country. I think that is regrettable—absolutely regrettable.

The third regret that I have in relation to your statement, Mr President, is that you did not attempt to confirm the statements of fact in the letter either with the Department or with any other Minister. We are not talking about a statement such as, `This man has a law degree' or `This man has some other degree'. I have been duped in that respect myself by people claiming to have educational qualifications which they did not have. I am not talking about that. I am talking about assertions that the head of another government has sought this Government's assistance—something that is well beyond the average thing one would put in a curriculum vitae. I am talking about a statement of fact that would be easily checked with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Both the question of whether President Kabua had sought the Australian Government's assistance and whether Mr Symons was actually an adviser to the President were easily checkable and should have been checked. You should not have relied simply on your memory of a bag of documents and your staffer's memory of a conversation.

My fourth regret is that you commenced your memo to the Prime Minister by referring to the fact that Senator Richardson, the then Minister, brought `a Mr Symons' to your office. This is a small regret but, nonetheless, it does give the impression that you had never met Mr Symons before in your life. Were I drafting something and referring to someone whom I knew—someone who had been in the Labor Party when I was a younger member of the Party; someone who was clearly well known to a number of people in the Labor Party—I would not have referred to that person as `a Mr So-and-so'. I would have spelt that out. Perhaps it is an oversight. Nonetheless, I regret that, to the extent that it is an oversight, it happened.

The fifth point about which I wish to express some regret is that you start your letter to Mr Lamb, `Dear Chris, I understand that you have already spoken with Greg Symons'. I know that this letter was signed some time after you actually had the meeting with Mr Symons—I think you went away, came back and the letter was ready for you to sign on a Friday. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that you have already spoken with Greg Symons. . .

Unless I have been tardy in reading the material or listening to what you have said, I am unaware of how you became aware that Mr Symons had already spoken to Mr Lamb. I would like to know how, when you signed this letter, you knew that Mr Symons had already spoken to Mr Lamb. I would particularly like to know who told you and what they told you of the conversation that Mr Symons had with Mr Lamb. I would be very interested in having the point clarified: how did you know only a week or two later that the conversation had taken place and what else did you know about it?

PARA.TAB: My sixth regret is that there are other matters on which the document is silent. The document is totally silent on whether Senator Richardson had asked other, perhaps more relevant, people—that is, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans)—to make arrangements for Mr Symons. Were I in your position, Mr President, and someone came to me and asked for some sort of helpful introduction to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Washington or elsewhere, my first question would be—partly because of the position that I would hold and partly because of wanting to be of greatest benefit to the person seeking assistance—`Why doesn't the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade write such an introduction and reference?'. The documents are silent about whether you in fact asked these questions of Senator Richardson or why, as the President of the Senate, you were being sought after as the person to write this introduction rather than a Minister of the Government.

Further, your documentation is silent on whether Mr Peppinck raised this matter with you on your return to the chamber on 4 May. I understand that your document says that on your return on 4 May there were a couple of questions asked about this. Actually, if you include all the questions, there were seven asked in the week that you returned. It was only when the question by Senator Bishop was asked about the use of the embassy or consulate in the United States that the penny actually dropped that perhaps something needed to be checked.

Mr President, I think this begs the question. Presumably, Mr Peppinck is not incompetent; he has some experience in foreign affairs. This matter was raised in the week when you were away and it was raised six or seven times during the week that you returned. Mr Peppinck has a decent understanding of foreign affairs. He certainly had some understanding of the degree to which this issue was growing. Your documentation is silent as to whether Mr Peppinck said anything.

It is not for me to offer you advice about what you should do. But I can tell you what I would do if someone from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade working for me had allowed a matter like this to brew for a week when I was away and allowed it to continue to brew for a week once I was back. I can tell you what I would do if I had someone working for me who had assisted in the meeting, had a conversation the following day with Mr Symons, reported back to you, and presumably drafted the letter that contains these factual errors. This was only in November. We are not talking about something in 1985, 1986 or 1987; we are talking about something that happened less than a year ago. If I had someone working for me who let all of that brew up, and then just sat there and said nothing, he would not be with me for much longer. I would be interested to hear when Mr Peppinck actually raised something with you as opposed to when the penny dropped in your mind that there was a serious problem.

There is a further point on which your documentation is silent, Mr President. Following the penny dropping in your mind late on the Thursday, what conversations were then had with Senator Richardson? As the document makes no reference to Senator Richardson coming back to you during the first week you were back—from 4 May onwards—is it the case that Senator Richardson has come down and asked you, as President of the Senate, to write a reference or introduction for someone? Knowing all that he must know about it, is it the case that he has sat there and had all these questions asked of him and said nothing to you about asking you to write such a reference or introduction, has pretended it has not happened? Is it the case that that is what happened over an entire week with someone you know well? I find that difficult to accept.

Last but very much not least, Mr President, although I do not say that it was inappropriate of you to write this letter, I do wonder whether it was. You refer in the letter to assistance being sought of the Australian Government. It is not my view that the President of the Senate is a part of the Government. Parliament is there to keep a check on the Executive of the Government. As I understand it, the President of the Senate, as is the Speaker of the House, is meant to be an impartial parliamentary office holder, yet here we have a letter from the President of the Senate saying, `This is what the Australian Government wants', as though you were a part of that Government when the very success of this chamber relies on you being impartial towards the Government and Opposition. In that sense, I do not say you should not have written the letter, Mr President, but I do say that if I were in your shoes I would not have, for the very reason that I outlined. The presidency of the Senate is meant to be an impartial position. Parliament is meant to keep a check on the Executive and if I were President of the Senate I would not be caught dead with my name on a letter tallying around what the Australian Government does.

Mr President, you may well remember long debates about this in the House of Representatives when Mr Snedden said that as an expression of his desire to remain impartial he would not even attend party meetings. I think, therefore, that he too would have been reluctant to write such a letter that ties in with the alleged wishes of the Australian Government. That does not mean, Mr President, that in holding the position you do you are not entitled—in fact, you would probably be wrong if you did not—to write letters seeking such assistance on behalf of Australian citizens. It is not that aspect of which I complain. It is the aspect of mentioning what the Australian Government wants on presidential letterhead. I think that is very regrettable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us a monstrously overblown proposition. We have an attempt to draw a conclusion which is extraordinarily out of proportion with the weight of the evidence that underlies it. Nothing with sufficient substance has been presented to justify the magnitude of the conclusion which is seeking to be drawn. We should not underestimate—I am sure the President does not—the significance of the Senate's grave concern at what is alleged to be the failure of the President to exercise due care and, I am sure more important to the President, the allegation that he has compromised the office of the President of the Senate. I do not think either of those allegations are to be taken lightly and I do not think either of those allegations are in any way justified by the facts that have been put forward.

PARA.TAB: What is being alleged about Senator Sibraa? A lot of questions are being asked. We had there in this most recent exercise yet another fishing expedition in questions about what might be here. They were questions without any substance at all. They were just throwing a hook down a hole in the hope that something might bite. After two hours of questions—we doubled the normal time allotted for Question Time—no fish were biting. We have had debates before in the Senate, and this debate has now been going for over an hour. There are still no fish being hooked; nothing has been landed. There is nothing to underpin this except an anxiety to keep a good issue going.

Before I go to the comments I want to make about the core elements of the motion proposed by Senator Hill and the circumstances as they surround the actions of the President in this matter, I want to respond to one issue—not to respond to all the fishing expeditions—that was raised by Senator Vanstone. She was concerned that the President had written a letter saying that somebody had sought the assistance of the Australian Government and that that in some way therefore implied that Senator Sibraa was lining himself up as a member of the executive arm of government rather than as a representative of the Parliament. That seems to me to be a very strange interpretation of the words. In the first event, Senator Sibraa was making the comments as a senator of the Australian Parliament in writing to an officer of the Australian Government saying, `This person has sought the Government's assistance. I am writing to the Government on this person's behalf'.

There was an implication in an earlier part of the debate that it is somehow unusual that the President should be the person who is approached in this matter. It does not seem to me to be of the order of magnitude that would have warranted an approach to people like the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), to whom reference was made. It should be a matter of pride to the President that he is well known around the Parliament as a person with significant expertise in the area of foreign affairs and as a person who has a wide range of contacts in governments around the world where he has had meetings not as an effective representative of the Australian Government but certainly as a very effective representative of Australia. He has done us proud in forums around the world in his various capacities as chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, as he was for a long period where he served very well, as President and in many other capacities. So I put those things on the record in response to the allegations in Senator Vanstone's address.

The alleged crime which justifies the conclusion that Senator Sibraa has compromised the office of President of the Senate is that he wrote a letter based on documents which looked at the time, and look at the moment, to be authoritative—documents which bear all the normal hallmarks which would be looked for as documents authentically produced on behalf of the Government of the Marshall Islands. There is nothing on the face of them which would indicate that they are other than that. There is nothing at this stage to establish that they are other than that.

Certain matters are being pursued in the Marshall Islands court that might indicate some questions now about the status of those documents, although that is certainly far from established. It may be that when that court case is concluded we can draw some conclusions about that document, but there is nothing in it to indicate that any senator presented with those documents would have concluded that it was reasonable to ask whether they were or were not bona fide documents from the Government of the Marshall Islands.

The nature of the request that was made of Senator Sibraa—he was not being requested to sign a treaty on behalf of Australia; he was not being requested to enter into negotiations on behalf of the Government of the Marshall Islands—was to write a letter to a middle-ranking officer of the Australian Government, whom he knew well, saying, `It would be useful if you could arrange some contacts for this person'. At the time of the meeting in November last year, without the benefit of hindsight and on the basis of any information any of us would have had at that time, those documents would have seemed to be of sufficient authority and stature to warrant the fairly modest level of action that Senator Sibraa was asked to take and which he did take.

If we consider this letter in the context of letters which have been written surrounding this matter by other senators about which we have had a debate in this House in the past—and I do not agree with the conclusion the Senate came to, but that is its right—it does not constitute a reference for Mr Symons. It is a letter of introduction, which is remarkably different from a reference. It does not say, `This is a person worthy of your endorsement'. It does not say, `I suggest you enter into business with this person because he is a pretty good bloke and of good repute'. It accurately describes what the documents before Senator Sibraa said, with one qualification, which he himself has made with hindsight. I think it is fair to say that we all concur with the President that he might well have better drafted the letter. But I would not say that the fact that six months ago the President might have somewhat better drafted a letter constitutes compromising the office of the President of the Senate by any reasonable assessment.

What is the second element of the allegations surrounding this matter? It is that as a result of these representations Senator Sibraa arranged a meeting through the normal channels with the appropriate officer in a manner in which the appropriate officer considered perfectly proper and perfectly normal. That is the second grave allegation. It is very hard to see how this compromises the office of the President of the Senate. If we are looking at what the crime is, what the President is being found guilty of, it is of course guilt by association. His really heinous crime is that he knows Senator Richardson. That is the matter of which he is guilty. Also, he met Symons, and apparently he met him in 1979 or some time around then; I think he said today in the Senate that it was 12 years ago. Having met him twice is a very serious offence, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Known him well some years ago, Senator. In Young Labor, I think.

—Now we are getting to the core of it. It is important that he knew him in 1979. In 1979 he might have met him. This is what has stirred the reaction. So it is a very serious crime to have met Greg Symons. I think a cousin of mine was married to a bloke who went broke in 1972. I probably should declare this to the Senate because this may be a very serious offence. Perhaps I should slash my wrists or perhaps my colleagues were aware of that this morning. This may have brought me undone this morning.
—Twenty votes, Bob.
—The other 79 must have known about this heinous offence that my cousin committed in 1972.
—They just thought you were hopeless.
—Just like those opposite thought Senator Durack was; I understand. I won my preselection, which is more than those opposite can say they did for their Deputy Leader.
—They just thought you were hopeless. That is why you got only 20 votes this morning. What a disgrace! How embarrassing!

—I would have thought my explanation was somewhat more substantial and relevant than that of Senator Knowles. The third serious allegation against Senator Sibraa is that he is a member of the New South Wales Right. This is the third element of his serious crime. It has nothing to do with the letter or the meeting but that he knows Senator Richardson, he has met Mr Symons and he is a member of the New South Wales Right. These are really the bases upon which we are being asked to judge him.
—Only that he knew him more than twice.

—However often he has met Mr Symons is a serious part of the Opposition's allegation. I cannot see where that is said in the motion. There is nothing in the Opposition's motion that says that this outrageous person had met Symons in 1979. That is not what it says. If that is the Opposition's allegation, why does it not have the guts to say that his serious offence is guilt by association? Those opposite try to pretend they have some serious basis in this flimsy bit of nonsense that their leader and others have put forward when in fact what they are saying—which is now clear—is that he is guilty by association.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about a person whom those opposite have quite properly described as a very good President of the Senate. Let us not through some tawdry little overblown exercise undermine the proper recognition which those opposite have quite appropriately paid Senator Sibraa for his impartiality and for the way he has handled a difficult job with dignity. These are things that those opposite have properly said about him and which I endorse. It is time that we stopped these allegations; that we stop not only the allegations in here but also the even more outrageous ones that have been made outside.

For example, there have been calls by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to stand the President down, which is exceeded in its outrageousness only by its stupidity. I suppose nobody should be surprised about that. It is an outrageous breach of the proper attitude which a leader of a political party should take towards the role of the Presiding Officer in the Parliament. Once again, that would not be a source of any wonder. On the evidence, there is nothing to substantiate the allegation that Senator Sibraa has compromised the office of the President of the Senate. Over the years that he has held that office he has discharged it with dignity. Those opposite have recognised that in the past and the Senate should recognise it again today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely concerned about the motion that has been moved by Senator Hill in that it does reflect on the President of our Senate not only because he compromised the office of the President of the Senate through his failure to exercise due care in requesting the Australian Embassy to assist Mr Symons and as a result made false assertions in his request but also because he has continued to compromise the office of the President through his subsequent actions relating to this letter for Mr Symons.

PARA.TAB: I draw attention to the fact that today in the Senate at Question Time Senator Evans said that on 7 May he received faxes of a bundle of documents, including the President's letter to Mr Lamb in Washington; that those documents were then used to prepare, on the afternoon of 8 May, a memo on the President's involvement with Mr Symons; and that that memo was then sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Senator Richardson and the President.

Mr President, I am afraid that leads to subsequent questions. They are questions which worry me almost as much as the fact that you had such a lapse of judgment in the way you dealt with a man who came in with a bag of documents. I ask why in your report to the Prime Minister you simply said:

SPEECH.PARA: Late Friday afternoon Mr Peppinck contacted me to let me know that a letter from myself to Mr Lamb had been located, and a copy of it was sent to me the following Saturday morning.

Did this letter not form part of the memo sent to you by Senator Evans out of that bundle of documents? Mr Miles Kupa, the public servant of Schlich Street, Yarralumla, acting for Senator Evans, said in his statutory declaration that the documents, including a copy of Sibraa's letter, were sent to the office—that was on the 7th—and that the letter became part of the memo, I understand. Did that letter not form part of the memo?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not sent on the 7th.
—Senator Evans said that this afternoon in Question Time, as I understand it.
—The response was sent on the 8th to the Parliament.

—No. I asked Senator Evans about that and he said that he did not communicate with Senator Sibraa or with Senator Richardson that day, which strains my belief in his answer because I would have thought the automatic thing, when he got a bundle of documents, would have been to immediately contact his colleague saying, `Do you know what has turned up?'. If Senator Evans has told us that he did not but that he got a memo prepared on the afternoon of the 8th and that it—
—So the document was sent on the 8th—we agree.
—I said that; I think you misheard me.
—You said the 7th.
—The 7th was when he received the faxes of the bundle of documents.
—You said they were sent on the 7th to Sibraa and Richardson.
—If I did, I meant to say the 8th; I believed I said the 8th.
—It is crucial to us.

—Yes, it is certainly important. But I am asking Senator Sibraa whether the letter formed part of the memo sent to him by Senator Evans or whether he found that letter amongst his own files. Mr President, you carefully did not say that in your statement to the Prime Minister. If it came through Senator Evans's memo, why did you report to the Prime Minister that a letter had been located and not mention how or where? If you found the letter amongst your own files, why did you not tell the Prime Minister that you had also received a memo from Senator Evans?

PARA.TAB: Once you had found the document from some source or another, did you then have discussions with Senator Richardson, Senator Evans or the Prime Minister about the matter? Senator Vanstone has already referred to this. It seems absolutely extraordinary and quite out of character that anybody involved in an issue which was then of some moment in the Parliament, having found that there were documents in which he was involved, did not contact the main players immediately.

Why did you not, Mr President, make a public statement as soon as you had received the document, which you say in your statement to the Prime Minister you received on Saturday 9 May? Why did you not inform the Prime Minister straightaway? Perhaps you did. Or did you wait until 15 May with your statement to communicate with the Prime Minister? Did you communicate with the Prime Minister in that time? You are well aware that this had become a very public issue and that you had relevant information on which you were sitting.

In your second letter to the Prime Minister, dated 21 May, you said that on the previous evening your senior adviser was told that a thorough search of departmental records had thrown up a letter from Mr Lamb responding to your letter of 20 November. You said that you had then had an exhaustive search of your office and found Mr Lamb's letter.

Why did your staff not recall such a letter previously and instigate such a search? That seems extraordinary. You knew by this stage that you had had an involvement. Why was a search not instigated much earlier? Why did you wait until you heard from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that it had found this letter?

You said in an attachment to your statement—which has no heading on it and which seems a strange, bald document; I would like an explanation of exactly what that document was, why it appears without a heading and solely in capitals—that you tabled today, that you have been aware since 7 May that, on receipt of your letter in Washington, it was forwarded to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra.

If you have been aware of that since 7 May, how were you so aware? Was it from Senator Evans's memo, which he says you did not get before 8 May? Which of you is correct? Did Senator Evans actually let you know earlier than 8 May, despite his denial of that today? If you became aware on 7 May of Mr Lamb's response to your letter, why did you not come into the Senate and inform the Senate there and then on 7 May?

You say yourself in the document that you tabled today that you were at a private dinner in your rooms that evening. You were perfectly able to come in here and make a statement about what you knew. What prevented you from informing the Senate that night of what you knew? Why did you lie low for so long?

Why have you been so totally silent in all this documentation of any communications between yourself and your colleagues Senator Richardson, Senator Evans and the Prime Minister? It makes these documents you have given us seem rather hollow, and that is what worries me.

You are the President of our Senate. We expect you to be scrupulous in all your dealings. You have acknowledged that you acted without due care in providing the letter. But you have also acted subsequently without full and open disclosure. Your subsequent statements have left us with only this series of questions about dates and about the state of your knowledge. They are questions that will have to be answered, Mr President. They cannot hang around your neck forever—they hang also around the neck of the Senate, because you are our President.

I am seriously concerned that you appear not to have been totally frank with this Parliament or the nation. I call on you urgently to answer these questions, which are not answered in the documentation that you have provided to us. They add to my serious concerns, and those of my colleagues, as set out in the motion before us tonight.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a lot about the office of President, and we have heard a lot of hypocrisy about it this afternoon. Generally on our side the inclination is to support a colleague and to accept a colleague's explanation. On the other side, there is not only a desire, I believe, to respect the office of President, but also a blood lust to try to get as many political victims as possible.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition are trying to tread a thin line in that regard. They are not trying to show disrespect for the office of the President. I am convinced of that, having listened to all the speakers. But they are trying to build up assertions and associations that either do not exist or have been fabricated by them. A very weak case has been presented here today to us who are the jurors in this case, albeit coming from our different political points of view.

It is a weak case, I suppose, because—I am sorry to say this, Senator Cooney—there are so many lawyers sitting opposite. It is a lawyer's mentality, unfortunately, that probably for once does not add to the deliberations of the Senate, but detracts from them.

I listened to Senator Hill's contribution. I guess I could have written his speech. I do not know how many times I would have written, `Pause to wring your hands'—probably 30 or 40 times. His speech was full of rhetorical questions, with no substance at all. But the lack of leadership in this chamber on the opposite side has been apparent to all of us for many years. It is the reason, if the coalition does happen to win government, that Mr Peacock will be the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and Senator Hill will be reduced to the ranks. So I was not at all impressed by his case.

I wanted to deal with one matter—and I hope I am interrupted if it has been dealt with fully—namely, Dr Hewson's comments last week that the present President of the Senate has no business with foreign affairs issues. Anyone who knows the offices of the Speaker and the President would know that there is a substantial involvement in foreign affairs. I will look at March and what the President had to do in foreign affairs in that month.

On 2 March, the President met the Mexican parliamentary delegation. On the same day there was a courtesy call by the Mongolian Vice-President and a dinner for the Mongolian delegation. On 3 March the President met the consultant to the PNG Prime Minister and there was a parliamentary dinner for the Mexican parliamentary delegation. He met the Zimbabwean Permanent Secretary, the Danish Ambassador and the Kuwaiti Ambassador. He attended a CPA meeting. He met a Russian delegation and held a dinner for the Russian delegation. There was a CPA working party on Malaysia. He met with the Speaker of the Malaysian Parliament and senior Malaysian parliamentary officials. I have pages on what the President does in foreign matters.

It is his duty to pass on his views to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to report the sorts of things that are raised. Every time the President of the United States comes to Australia he meets the President of the Senate. When the Queen comes to Australia, she meets the President of the Senate. So continually Presidents and Speakers are involved in foreign issues. Dr Hewson's assertion was absolutely and totally without foundation.

Senator Alston and Senator Newman raised the question of why there was no statement on 8 May. I do not think Senator Sibraa could have got out his report and the information on it any more quickly than he did. I was amazed at how quickly he responded to the request by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It was a request, not a demand, because the Prime Minister said, `As President of the Senate, you have no obligation to report to me'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could have come in here and told us about his letter on the 7th.

—I will come back to that point. Senator Sibraa tried to get the information to all honourable senators, through their leaders, as quickly and expeditiously as possible, and he is to be commended for that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston cruelly went on and implied that, had it not been for other events in respect of documentation, Senator Sibraa would never have made a statement. I do not believe that. From my knowledge of Senator Sibraa, I believe he would have. I believe that Senator Sibraa, with the information available, would have made a statement.

Let us come to the question of how well Senator Sibraa knows Mr Symons, because this really is at the heart of guilt by association. It also tests people's judgments of political credibility. The first assertion made is, `Senator Sibraa must have known Mr Symons because they were in Young Labor together'. I do not wish to stress the point while you are in the chair, Mr President, but you are 55 now.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year.

—Mr Symons is 43. They were not, to my knowledge—and I think Senator Sibraa would assert—in the Young Labor association at the same time. Senator Sibraa—and no-one has challenged this—said that he had not met Mr Symons for the previous 12 years. But Senator Newman and everyone else says, `Surely you remembered Mr Symons'. We meet thousands of people in politics. I am regarded as having one of the best memories in the Labor Party but there are people I forget, unfortunately.
—Really!

—Yes, people who may have been in Young Labor from 1966 to 1972, or whenever I was there. Unfortunately I do not remember all of their names. To suggest that Senator Sibraa should have had a total recollection of Mr Symons rather than a vague one is really pushing the point. I would like to ask Senator Alston how many branch members he remembers when he was chasing preselection from one end of Victoria to another—because he had to chase a lot of seats before they finally put him in B grade here. I wonder how many members' names he can recollect—members whom he doorknocked and telephoned then.

PARA.TAB: It is possible that we do not recall everyone we meet in politics. I do not, and I challenge anyone here to do so. A previous President, Mr Doug McClelland, had the all-time record memory in this regard, and I bet he did not remember everyone. But he remembered most. So I think that is a totally fallacious point.

Senator Alston goes on to say, `Were notes taken of the meeting?'. I do not think anyone knows whether notes were taken. What probably happened was what happens in my office. If the stuff looks important and really exciting, they take notes. If it is to do with foreign governments or substantial business ideas, we keep the notes, but others we throw out a week or two later. We do not record all notes of all conversations. One of the reasons I do not do that is not that I am afraid of what will be recorded; I am afraid that the people who take notes do not get everything down in that period.

Senator Alston has asked whether there are any notes. We do not think there are any notes. Senator Sibraa quite properly directed his staff to undertake a most comprehensive search of his own records and has not turned them up. Note that when something else has turned up that honourable senators opposite have known nothing about he has not hesitated to put it on the public record. The reply letter from, I think, Mr Lamb was properly put on the public record, without honourable senators opposite having known anything about it, because we want to be as fulsome as possible.

I suppose that Senator Alston goes on and says, `Why did the President not wake up earlier in the week? Was he half awake? Was he not paying attention at Question Time?'. I am sorry, honourable senators opposite will have to add me to the motion. I do not listen to every part of Question Time. It was only on the Thursday when the linkage was made that Senator Sibraa's memory was jolted. People tend not to challenge that. They ask why a member of his staff did not remember this. It might surprise honourable senators opposite, but not all staff members watch Question Time assiduously. They are doing other duties. Only one or two of my staff are delegated to watch Question Time; the others get on with their work.

In regard to the letter itself, Senator Alston described it as a glowing reference. I would not be quite that excessive. It was a normal sort of courteous reference as written—just like the Liberal Minister in a previous government gave the letters of introduction to all our embassies for Frank Nugan. I do not challenge that Liberal Minister's integrity. He is still on the front bench. In fact, I have no question, because he thought at the time, as did a lot of other people, that Mr Nugan was a reasonable and fair businessman. We know differently now. Nevertheless, there was someone who held a position slightly more prominent than President Sibraa's and who sent those letters out to our embassies and gave them to Mr Nugan.

I am not surprised that Mr Lamb has said that he regarded the letter from Senator Sibraa as being just like other letters he gets from members and senators. But I would have to concede—and it is the one point I do concede—that it may have impressed him a little more than if it had come from a backbencher, but not as much as if it had come from a Minister. I do not mean to demean the office of President there, Mr President, but people usually rank these things in some sort of order in their own minds. All I can say to Senator Alston is thank goodness no barrister's fee is required.

Senator Alston goes on to say that in some ways Senator Sibraa was wrong to report to the Prime Minister and not to the Senate. I do not have full details of the timing of this. As I said before, the Prime Minister invited Senator Sibraa. He did not direct him, nor could he, because Senator Sibraa is responsible to the Senate. As soon as the report became available, my understanding is that Senator Sibraa sent it to Senator Coulter and Senator Hill, I think, and other Independent senators—straight away, without hesitation. Naturally, that put it in the public domain. He also, I think, released it to the press for them to comment on. So, having made his full investigation, he took the first available opportunity to make that involvement known.

We have the question of how much Senator Sibraa should have checked. I guess that the next time he writes a letter he will check a little more deeply. There is no question about that. He will also make sure that the phraseology of the letter is better. He has already expressed regret on that point. I suppose that no-one over there, though, has ever written a letter or put out a press release that was not word perfect. I am getting a lot of press releases from the other side now of how I have reduced the Australian Army from four battalions to six, press releases in which there are millions of grammatical errors and in which the figures never add up.

People do make mistakes. Mr Downer makes mistakes. Senator Sibraa's letter, especially in that crucial phrase that we have been over time and time again here, should have been better phrased. He admits that. That is not a hanging offence. It is nothing other than a trivial mistake. But it does reflect somewhat on the pressure that people are under when they sign letters and when they have a heavy workload. We concede that we all should take more care. Senator Vanstone makes the point that Senator Sibraa should have known Mr Symons better, et cetera. I have already answered that point.

We then get all the rhetorical questions. Had Senator Richardson asked anyone else? That was inserted into this debate with not the slightest bit of evidence. Should Senator Sibraa, in his busy schedule, not have taken time off, grabbed Senator Richardson and said, `Now, who else have you asked to write a reference or a letter of introduction for Mr Symons?'. What absolute rubbish!

Senator Vanstone made a point I find intriguing. She said, `Senator Sibraa should be independent. He should be like the great Speaker Snedden—above politics. What a wonderful person he was to be above politics'. If honourable senators walk around this building, they can see Speaker Snedden writ large where he sought revenge on all those who frustrated him in his career. The Opposition executive meeting room was specifically designed as a very small room so that we would be embarrassed when we occupied it. Bad luck, Mr Snedden, we are still here.

A whole series of design faults—and some honourable senators opposite know this as well as I do—were put there deliberately by Speaker Snedden to dud Prime Minister Fraser. So when people come up to me and tell me that he was the ideal independent Speaker I think, `What a load of absolute rubbish!'. Mr President, you do not have to ape Speaker Snedden. You have done the job fairly in this chamber over the years you have held the office. You have not hesitated to sit Ministers down, much to their displeasure at times. You have not hesitated to discipline either side. I think you have behaved in the great tradition of Senate Presidents—with fairness and objectivity. I know that this motion today will not alter that, and the Opposition does not intend it to do so. We will continue to have fair guidance from the Chair in this place.

I thought it was interesting that honourable senators opposite had no difficulty in approaching Mr President today to tell him the running order of their speakers. They did not really despise him. They were quite happy to wander up there and say, `Here is the next question to go to so and so'. They did not say, `By the way, he is going to attack you'. The relationship was totally normal. This is just a political ploy. It is a weak one. Let us face it, we have had a big match build-up to this. We were told what a massive Question Time we were to have today. `We need two hours for Question Time', we were told in the press.

What a pathetic performance it was. It cleared the gallery in no time. They were all wandering around the building saying, `What happened? Why didn't they ask any questions that mattered? Why didn't they turn up anything new?' Honourable senators opposite promised us this big two-hour Question Time. They probably expected us to resist it. We knew they had nothing to raise that was relevant. We were happy to have two hours. I guess the only reason we did not have three is that Senator Button and I wanted to go and have a smoke.

In summary, the case so far adduced by the Opposition, to support not a censure motion but, nevertheless, a serious motion against the President, is weak in the extreme. It is mostly based on asking rhetorical questions, as though there are conspiracies hiding under every bed. Mr President, I have total confidence in the way you have handled this matter. I appreciate the fact that you have expressed regret as to the way your letter was phrased. I believe that you have upheld the highest principles of propriety that this chamber would expect of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with your statement, Mr President, I think it is important that we also deal with the statutory declaration tabled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) as part of his answer to the question that I asked him today drawing his memory to my original question of 7 May that he investigate dealings between Mr Symons and the United States Embassy and/or consulates. Mr President, you will recall, as everybody else will recall, that Senator Evans said on that occasion that he simply did not know anything about it and that he was not going to inquire into it, either.

PARA.TAB: It is quite curious, I think, in looking at all the material that has come before us, to go right back to taws and to ask why Senator Richardson chose to bring Mr Symons to see you, Mr President. Why did he choose you, Senator Sibraa—the President of the Senate—when he could have gone to Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who would have met the criterion, the so-called reason that he went to you, far better? It was because you had better contacts in the United States than did Senator Richardson.

Senator Richardson made this statement in an interesting interview that he gave with John Laws and that predated the handing over of his now infamous statement to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). In that interview with John Laws, Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I introduced Greg Symons to him in a sense—
referring to you, Mr President. He continued:
He already knew him because Greg had been a member of the Labor Party, although he has not been for 10 years, and I introduced him to him and asked him to help him.
Laws said:
To help him in what sort of way?
Senator Richardson replied:

As I have said in the Senate the other day, Mr Symons had asked me for the names of officials he might be able to contact in the United States about his scheme. I did not know anyone but Kerry Sibraa who has had a much longer closer association with the United States than I may have known someone, so I asked Senator Sibraa if he could spare a few minutes to find out.

Surely, if Senator Richardson wanted to introduce Mr Symons to someone who had good contacts in the United States, he would have taken him to Senator Evans. But he did not choose to do that. He chose to take him to you, and this is where the worry is. The worry is that it is the old mates game in action. The fact is that Senator Richardson, the much proclaimed numbers man of the Right of the Labor Party, controlled the numbers that would control your preselection. Senator Richardson brought Mr Symons to see you on 12 November, and your preselection took place on 11 December.

PARA.TAB: We still have not got to the bottom of who wrote the letter. We have in your statement simply a statement that the letter was drafted and handed to you and that you signed it. You have said that Senator Richardson did not dictate the letter to you. We still do not know who drafted that letter for and on your behalf. When Senator Richardson said to John Laws that it was a scheme, my God he was right.

TALK.START.PARA: —A scam.

—It was an absolute disgraceful scam. The `prospectus document', and I can only describe it as a prospectus document, dated 11 August, which Senator Baume showed the Senate in Question Time today, showed that the scheme was this: Mr Symons and a variety of consultants, together with Multiplex, were promoting a high-tech complex and education centre—a high-tech park, I think it is called—to be built in the Marshall Islands at a cost of $40m and to be built by Multiplex. In that prospectus there was a photograph of Mr Ross MacGibbon, who was going to be in charge of this project. Mr Ross McGibbon, of course, has had dealings with Senator Richardson before, as we have now seen on the public record.

PARA.TAB: The complex was to be built for this $40m but was to be paid for by what I can only describe as a disgraceful scheme. That scheme was to sell passports to the Marshall Islands to Asian `investors'. They were being told that, with this passport and by taking citizenship, they would get access to the United States. The prospectus says:

SPEECH.PARA: In return for citizenship of the Republic, participants in the program will invest in the trust which will finance, develop, market and operate the Marshall Islands technology park.

There was a big hiccup in this plan: under the agreement between the United States and the Marshall Islands, it was only natural-born citizens of the Marshall Islands who got that privilege, not foreigners who had bought their way in. In order for those people who bought their citizenship to get access to the United States there would have to be a change to the United States law. How do I know that? Because I read the remarkable statutory declaration sworn by Mr Miles Kupa, public servant, working in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, who said, on a note concerning Gregory Symons:

PARA.TAB: When Symons called me on 25 November he explained that the business proposition he was promoting in the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) depended for its success on obtaining a change to the independence charter of the RMI, which could be done through US legislation. He said RMI independence arrangements allowed natural-born RMI citizens to have rights of free entry, including work, in the USA. His proposition involved the development of a Technology Park in the RMI through investment inducements—

SPEECH.PARA: a lovely word, `inducements'. He went on:

which would confer RMI citizenship on persons who invested a minimum of $250,000 in the park. Obtaining that investment, he said, would be relatively easy if the USA were to extend the same rights of entry and work to those citizens as to those natural-born.

Part of the letters given to you, Mr President, which have suddenly turned up from the United States in the Foreign Affairs file, was indeed the letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Marshall Islands. In the most significant part of this letter from the Minister of Foreign Affairs, on which you tell us you relied in part to write your reference—and it is not true to say that it is not a reference; it is a reference, because you are giving him the imprimatur of the Australian Government—it says:

This letter confirms that Mr. Greg Symons and Mr. Paul Finch are appointed as consultants to the Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Ambassador of the Republic of the Marshall Islands to the United States of America for the purpose of advising and negotiating with representatives of the United States on the clarification of and amendments to the Compact of Free Association.
This is the important bit. The letter goes on to state:

This appointment is solely for the purpose of the establishment of a Business Migration Program in the Marshall Islands, whereby investors granted citizenship in the Marshall Islands would receive no less favourable treatment than native-born citizens of the Republic for the purposes of entering into the United States of America.

In other words, this man, Mr Symons, was using every contact he had in the book to get himself access to people in the United States to change the legislation to meet his scam. This is the man to whom the President of the Senate gave a reference. Furthermore, if we want to go back under the `old mates Act' to see the sorts of things Mr Symons used to get into, a nice little paragraph appears on the business pages of the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday, 21 May 1992 headed `Symons' life before Richo' which states:
Greg Symons, the man at the centre of the Richo affair, certainly has had some interesting business links during the past few years.

CBD hears Symons was involved in a land deal at Port Stephens north of Newcastle, which became something of a local cause celebre, after blocks on the shores of picturesque Myall Lakes were sold before zoning approval was granted.

Greg's fellow participants in the deal included Eastern Suburbs property behemoth John Lyons, who once had close links with Sir Ron Brierly, and another well known gadfly about town Russell `She Wears My Ring' Goward. Goward's involvement in the affair caused great consternation among his colleagues, particularly Sir Ron, and eventually contributed to his exit from IEL.

Whether that icon of the Gold Coast white shoe brigade, Brian Ray, was involved in that particular deal is a little difficult to determine although the Bananaland property developer certainly has been linked to Symons.
The Port Stephens land deal involved the purchase of huge tracts of land, subdivision and sale to what turned out to be mug punters.
Unfortunately, the local regulators never allowed any dwellings on the blocks as State and local authorities are unwilling to extend the much promised roads and basic services to the land.

Mr Symons has not changed his ways much; whether it is flogging off land to unfortunate punters in the Newcastle area or selling off passports and citizenship in the Marshall Islands to punters who think they are going to get access to the United States. The only trouble is that they have to change the law in the United States.

PARA.TAB: Somewhere in my readings during the last several days I managed to see an interesting curriculum vitae of Mr Symons and his links with the well known front runners of the Sussex Street brigade. Of course, it goes back to the time when you, Mr President, were an office bearer in Sussex Street and responsible for dealing with Young Labor and when there were known instances of Mr Symons being found a job on a ministerial staff during the Whitlam years. On and on it goes. In other words, Mr Symons is not an unknown quantity. When Senator Richardson said to you that Mr Symons was known to you, Mr President, he meant it—Mr Symons was known to you. Senator Richardson did not really have to introduce you. Sure, you may not have seen much of Mr Symons and might not have wanted to write that letter, either. I can understand that, but Senator Richardson controls the numbers in New South Wales, and you knew it. If he asked you to write a letter, you would write the letter. That is why he went to you and why he did not go to Senator Evans.

Senator Evans is not off the hook either. Senator Evans gave us a lot of gobbledegook about why he could not possibly tell the Senate about all these documents until today. He told us it was too late on Thursday, 7 May for him to let us see the information that he had to hand. There is a problem with that. I had a look at the Hansard which shows that at 3.54 p.m. on 7 May I stood to take note of Senator Evans' answer earlier in the day. Senator Evans rose to respond to what I had to say at 3.57 p.m. On top of the letter that is attached to the statutory declaration of Mr Kupa—the one referred to by my colleague Senator Newman—that is, the copy of the undated letter faxed to the United States by Senator Sibraa on 20 November, is the information that it came from DFAT on 7 May at 3.53 p.m. In other words, Senator Evans had ample time to come back into the Senate at any time between then and two minutes past 11 when the Senate rose and bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that these documents had been brought to his attention by his own Department.

I want to know at whose instigation or on whose volition this statutory declaration was sworn? I suspect it may have been sworn by Mr Kupa on his own volition due to concern for his own reputation. He wanted it on the record that he was doing the right thing. He thought that if he did not swear a statutory declaration and get it out the truth of this matter may never come to fruition. When one reads his statement, the statement of Mr Lamb and the statement to Graham Richardson, one sees that the story lines do not exactly stack up.

As I said, all along this disgraceful scam was designed to dupe the United States Government by using Mr Symons as an instrument to try to change legislation to allow him to flog off citizenship in the Marshall Islands to get entry into the United States. What a disgraceful situation. That sort of scam has already been well and truly noted in Mr Symons' past dealings with regard to land deals in the Newcastle area.
Another interesting aspect in the documentation produced by Senator Evans is the memo sent to Senator Richardson—which he says he never saw—which outlines the scam. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the treaty between the Marshall Islands and the USA known as the `Compact of Free Association', citizens of the Marshall Islands are entitled to enter the USA with a valid passport but without the need for any visa or other documentation. They can own property, work and reside in the USA. Similar entitlements apply to USA citizens entering the Marshall Islands.

As I said before, when one reads Mr Lamb's statement he says that Mr Symons told him that that is in fact not true. It all depended—and I repeat—upon the United States extending the same rights of entry and work to those citizens who were natural born.

PARA.TAB: There is another discrepancy that comes out of this statutory declaration. Mr Kupa says that on the afternoon when I asked the question—and in response to that question Senator Evans said he was not aware of any dealings between Mr Symons and the Australian embassies—he telephoned Mr O'Leary to establish whether the Department knew of any such dealings. He was not instructed to do that. That is interesting, is it not? The Minister said that he would not investigate, but an officer who was paying attention immediately began the investigation. Was it the fact that he did not want to be caught out the way in which others had been caught out over the Brian Burke affair?
Mr O'Leary then replied to Mr Kupa. The statutory declaration reads this way:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that there may have been such dealings, in Washington.
The next sentence reads:

Senator Sibraa had written to the Embassy to ask if it could facilitate meetings for Mr Symons in Washington. A copy of this letter had been sent by the Embassy to the Department at the time. In the context of a telephone conversation with me —
and this is Mr O'Leary speaking—

in early April (Note: 6 April), about Mr Symons's court appearance in the Marshall Islands, he had mentioned the possibility of a meeting between Mr Symons and the Washington Embassy and had referred to the Sibraa letter. He had then faxed some documents about the Symons case, including a copy of Senator Sibraa's letter to this Office.

That is a statement that said that that letter was faxed to the Sydney office on 6 April. Mr Kupa said in response that he had no memory of that conversation with Mr O'Leary or the early part of it other than that it related to Symons's own court case. The statutory declaration continues:

. . . but that, while he had been talking about Washington to me, a recollection of some reference on his part to a Symons-Washington connection in the earlier conversation had come to me. However, I did not recall him having referred at that time to a letter from Senator Sibraa. Nor did I recall seeing a copy of such a document, which I thought I would have.
