I asked Mr O'Leary to undertake a check of his Branch's files and to send copies of the documents relating to the possibility of contact between Mr Symons and the Washington Embassy to me as soon as possible.
4. Mr O'Leary undertook to do so and later that afternoon the documents (copies attached, marked A to F), including a copy of Senator Sibraa's letter, were sent to the office and I received them.
5. I have no recollection of seeing the documents, including the Sibraa letter, prior to their receipt in the Office on the afternoon of 7 May.
He said:
I conveyed the documents to Senator Evans later that afternoon—
this is still 7 May—
after his second exchange with Senator Bishop in the Senate.
He gave the documents to Senator Evans. It continues:
I had not informed Senator Evans earlier of my 6 April conversation with O'Leary—Senator Evans was overseas . . .
He does not believe there was any other information.

PARA.TAB: On the day that I asked the question, Senator Evans had that information and simply did not come back into the Senate and admit that it was available. Of course, it included the new letter, the one dated 4 December, that Senator Sibraa had unfortunately filed. It is the first time that we really get a date for Senator Sibraa's original letter, because the one that was faxed was undated. This letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your letter of 20 November concerning the visit to Washington of Greg Symons and Paul Finch, whose visit enabled them to discuss with US officials opportunities for stimulating business development in the Republic of the Marshall Islands.

This letter is written by Mr Christopher Lamb, the same Mr Christopher Lamb who wrote in his statement that Mr Symons had said that this whole scam depended on the United States changing its legislation. The letter goes on:
We were able to have a useful briefing session in the Embassy and over a fast-food lunch with Greg and Paul —
Old friends by now, are they, Greg and Paul? It continues:

. . . which aimed at offering them a useful opportunity to size up the possibilities. In subsequent conversations they said they seemed to have met the right people and to have come away with some fresh ideas as to how best to organise their business.
That is, subvert the course of legislation in another country. It continues:

On another note, we are looking forward to seeing you in Washington on 11 January. The plan, as discussed with Fred Peppinck, is to have a good working dinner with senior leadership personnel from both Houses of the Congress. We should also have an opportunity to discuss other (more Australian) matters during the morning of 12 January.

This is all very chummy, folksy stuff. It is all, `Dear Chris'; it is all, `Greg and Paul had a nice lunch'. Mr President, this is not a formal letter written about somebody about whom you knew nothing; this is all the old mates act.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, it saddens me, because I really do believe that you would not have chosen to write that letter of your own volition. I really do believe that pressure was brought upon you to write it for the reasons I have set out. The problem is that you put the imprimatur of the Australian Government on a man who is a worthless individual, who has bought disrepute upon this country and who has finally brought at least one Minister undone, if not more to follow.

Mr President, it is not good enough to say that, given your druthers, you would have phrased the letter a little differently. I bet you would. Given your druthers, you wish you would have said no to Senator Richardson when you were asked to help a mate. I can understand that when you wrote it there was no way in the world you thought it would end up in this mess. You probably thought it would go unknown. But at the end of the day, Mr President, we still have to know who drafted the letter and the pressure that was brought to bear—and I guess you are going to have to say that no pressure was brought to bear.

You are going to have to say why, when you really did know more about this individual—or, if you did not, it was so easily accessible for you to know more about him—you chose to recommend him as a respectable businessman. In fact, he was a man promoting a scam; a man who had a history of promoting scams. We have to know why it was that you chose to put the imprimatur of the Australian Government under the letterhead of the President of the Senate and, truly, not only bring the Senate into disgrace but also the Australian Government.

I might disagree with the policies of the Government of the day, I might disagree with things that it does, but as far as people who go offshore and represent us outside this country are concerned, I want to be proud of my country. I want to say, `This is a fine country, the people have chosen this Government at the present time and I expect it to behave in a certain way'. It gives me no joy at all to see that people in a foreign land will see that those in the Government have acted in an improper way. There are still questions that need to be answered. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, given the approach that those opposite have taken in this matter, there will always be questions to ask. No matter what you say, there will be straw men and, in this day of non-sexism, straw women put up by those opposite for you to knock over.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you have made a clear statement of your position. It is clear to everybody what you say. This Senate will decide that you are an honourable man and a good President and will vote accordingly. Indeed, the only people who will vote against you, if a vote is taken, are those in the coalition. They will vote along party lines. I have said again and again that not one single person from the other side will not vote against you, and not one single person on this side will not vote for you. Firstly, I will talk about flawed institutions. As one dedicated to dealing with these matters—and we seem to deal with them all the time—this institution is flawed by the very results we get time and again when these sorts of motions are moved.

The only one thing I can say about what I heard of the last speech is that it should assure you, Mr President, to stay right where you are. Senator Bishop sometimes treats some people's characters more robustly than those of other people in the chamber. In her speech, which went for almost half an hour—longer than anybody else—she attacked Senator Evans with some savagery. She also attacked Senator Richardson. She made references to the Brian Burke affair. She said that Mr Kupa had made his affidavit obviously to protect himself and that he had no merit. She treated nobody kindly in the speech that she has just made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The point I made about Mr Kupa, the Foreign Affairs official, is that he indeed was acting responsibly and properly. I would not want anyone to misinterpret that.

—Senator Bishop says that she has treated one person with respect; I accept that. She has denigrated everybody else and treated them as people whose characters have no decency. That is not inconsistent with other statements and other speeches she has made. In that context, she really has not attacked you, Mr President, except to say that you signed a letter that you should not have signed. On her scenario, she said that you did not even write the letter. I accept that Senator Bishop—because this is what she says, by inference at least—writes all her letters. Every letter that goes out of Senator Bishop's office is written by her, although I presume they are typed by one of her staff.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I am most interested that Senator Cooney seems to know so much about what everybody else does. Could he please address the subject at hand.

When she attacked you, Mr President, in the restrained way that she had to, it was an indication that there is really no evidence at all against you. You have acted as President in this chamber. I have noted and listened to all the speeches made here today and there has not been one attack upon you in your capacity as the President and to act impartially and properly as a President. There has not been one skerrick of evidence that indicates that you are not amongst the most excellent of Presidents ever to have graced this chamber—and there have been some great Presidents of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: It has been said that because you, Mr President, have written a letter you should be treated in a fashion which would humiliate any person in your position. I will come back to that. Let us assume that the Opposition is correct about the letter. The Opposition has not had the ability when looking at this matter to weigh in the balance the great work that you have done for this Senate and the way you have represented this country overseas.

The words of this motion say that you, Mr President, did not take due care. What is due care? Had you written this letter to the Ambassador of the United States or to some head of Government, you may have expressed it differently. But, as I understand what you said, you wrote to a congressional liaison officer, someone you know, and asked him to give help, if possible, to this person. You did not ask him to introduce this person to a specific person; you asked whether he could help him. This is a person whom you know and who knows the system. This is a person within the Embassy who takes the appropriate action, who feeds it back through the system and who takes these people for a quick meal. To say that this is trying to corrupt the legislative process of the Congress is an absurd statement when those people looking at this would be well equipped with advice. The people who are elected to Congress, the people in the Senate and government officials in the United States are hardly the sort of people who will be duped by a scheme such as this. The statements you relied on were statements which, when you read them and took them at face value, as you were entitled to, had considerable strength. People have admitted in their arguments—they have found it difficult to get around and have not got around—that if somebody arrived on their doorstep with a letter from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs from any state and a letter from the Cabinet of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, they would have been persuaded that that person had, as he did have, authority from the Government of the Marshall Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a very specific, sleazy purpose.
—What Senator Bishop says from that last remark is that the people in on this scam were from the Government of the Marshall Islands.
—No, it was Symons.

—I would like Senator Bishop to look at the Hansard when it comes out. I was talking about these letters from the Marshall Islands. As I spoke about them, her inference was that they were part of a sleazy scam. If they were, that is nothing against Senator Sibraa because he was entitled to look at these letters from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and from the office of Cabinet and to act upon them. We should look at the way he acted upon them. If we look at the letter that he wrote, there is no reference to Greg Symons's character. He described him factually and within the sphere of his knowledge as a commercial lawyer and businessman and an adviser to the President of the Republic of the Marshall Islands. Senator Bishop should show me where in that letter there is any more than a request to the congressional liaison officer, Christopher Lamb, to see what he can possibly do. He does not override the judgment which no doubt he expected Mr Lamb to make as to what he ought or ought not do. There is nothing that has followed as a consequence of this letter that would in any way indicate that the United States Government was ever affected by it, let alone ever knew about it.
—What did George Bush think?

—That question, no doubt asked facetiously, bears out exactly the problem that the Opposition faces. This letter has been treated in the very way that the President when he wrote it intended it to be treated—as a request by a friend, Christopher Lamb, to help these people if he could. That is all that has happened. That is the trouble with the Opposition's case. Where is the evidence that this has produced any results in the United States? Where is the evidence that this letter has brought this Senate into disgrace? Where is the evidence that it has brought this country into disgrace? It is a hyperbole to allege that it has. There is no evidence of it. It is used in an emotional way by Senator Bishop to raise a case against the President.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop does not really want to get the President; she wants to get Senator Evans. If we look at her speech we will see that that is what she is on about. She wants to get Senator Evans, not Senator Sibraa. Everybody likes Senator Sibraa. To use that old phrase, she is wanting to wound—Senator Evans—but is afraid to strike. So she turns her guns on the President, a man who has done no more than act in a way consistent with a senior Cabinet Minister, whom he has known for years and respects, bringing a person to him, consistent with the letters that this person had from the Government of the Marshall Islands, and consistent with his own sense of decency and fair play.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of other points. The President's affiliation with the Australian Labor Party has been raised. No doubt, the day will come when the office of President will be held by an honourable senator from the other side. Comment has been made on the political pressures on such a person. I think it is true that there are such pressures. I have had occasion to look at a work entitled An Encyclopedia of Parliament by Norman Wilding and Philip Laundy. Referring to the office of Speaker in England, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The quality most essential to a Speaker is strict impartiality . . .
I think the President has clearly demonstrated that, as has the Deputy President. It continues:
One of his most important duties is to protect the rights of minorities and to ensure that their voices are heard.
The President has certainly done that. The encyclopaedia continues:
Once elected, he forgets party affiliations and is immune to external influences in any form.
In England, the custom is that once a Speaker is elected by the Parliament, that is the end of the matter; he or she is immune from challenge. That is the rule. However, as this encyclopedia states:

In Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, for instance, the Speakership is regarded as a privilege of the party in power, and the occupant of the Chair usually changes with the Government. The Speaker is generally opposed in his constituency during a General Election, and fights for his seat along partisan lines like any other candidate.

If the Opposition is concerned that political influence is brought to bear on the President—be it the current President or any other President—it should make him immune from future elections by giving him a seat or a position on a combined Senate paper where he is immune. It is not to the point to say that, as a member of a party, the President, or anybody else, has associations within that party. It is quite clear that that is so.

PARA.TAB: I wish to tell a story. I was friendly with a young doctor some years ago—he has since become a very eminent doctor—who attended someone who was injured at Dandenong. That person was taken to hospital, where he later died from gunshot wounds. A murder trial followed. My friend was put into the box and heavily cross-examined by an eminent lawyer, Frank Galbally, and taken to task over why he did not take note of various things which were pertinent to the murder trial. As my friend said, he had many things on his mind at that time, not the least of which was to save a person's life. This is an illustration of how it is very easy to look at things in hindsight and with a specific purpose in mind. Richard II, on returning from Ireland and finding his kingdom in revolution, said, `Call back yesterday'. I suppose we would all like to call back yesterday. Those of us examining what the President did on the occasion in question are in the very happy position of having before us all of the material and all of the knowledge that we need about Mr Symons and his activities. We can made a judgment. That is an unfair way, in my view, to judge this. A person should be judged in the context of what he did at the time.
As has been pointed out, on that occasion a person equipped with a strong endorsement

SPEECH.PARA: from a government which he said he represented—and in fact did so represent—was introduced to the President by an eminent member of the Cabinet. The President wrote a letter to a person whom he knew within the foreign affairs Department, knowing that person would check up, as that person did, and that he would exercise his proper judgment. He did no more than indicate to Mr Symons where else he might make inquiries. That is what happened on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: The result was as expected. Mr Symons made such efforts without obtaining the result that he sought. The service that the President performed on this occasion had the expected result; a letter of request was given to somebody to do something for someone who seemed to have the proper credentials. It was not a big thing; he was simply pointed in the direction of where he might make further inquiries. It was not a letter to any ambassador or to any official of the American Government or any other government; it was a letter to a person whom he knew through his work in the President's office. It was the sort of letter which many of us might write in the circumstances.

The President has come away from this debate unchallenged in terms of his job in this chamber. That is the interesting thing. Nothing has been said against Senator Sibraa; there has been nothing but praise for the way in which he has operated in this chamber. He has been attacked on something which is peripheral to his main function. Even if it were a main part of his function, he has carried it out in a proper fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament is sitting for the first time in two weeks. Since we began our sitting six hours ago, the greatest part of the time has been concentrated on the Symons affair. Senator Richardson, who was a Cabinet Minister, resigned from the Ministry because of the way in which he failed to give full and proper answers to this Senate and his failures as a Minister, all to do with his relationship with his cousin, a Sydney businessman and former ALP mate, Greg Symons.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the matter that has been more directly before us has been that which has flowed from your statement to this chamber the minute we resumed. You gave us a statement of some two pages, to which is attached the statement you gave to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 15 May and some related correspondence. In response to the statement you made in the Senate about this current matter, the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, has moved:

That the Senate take note of the President's statement and expresses its grave concern that the President of the Senate failed to exercise due care in requesting the Australian Embassy in Washington to assist Mr Symons and, as a result, made false assertions in his request, thus compromising the Office of the President of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am very glad that you are now in the chair to respond to those who have spoken in the Senate this afternoon and this evening. As I understand it, I am the last speaker from this side of the Senate in the debate. I hope that you will speak to this motion and answer the relevant matters and questions that were raised, not least by my Liberal colleagues.

PARA.TAB: I believe, Mr President, that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and my five Liberal colleagues who have spoken in this debate have sustained the motion. No-one has shown here today that there was not a failure on your part to exercise due care in your request to the Australian Embassy in Washington, and no-one has shown that you did not make false assertions in that request. Indeed, refreshingly, you acknowledged in your statement that you did make errors in the letter that was written. You acknowledged that you had taken this person who was introduced to you by your colleague, a Labor Minister, on face value. Your excuse was that this person, to the extent that he was some con man—not only before you but also, it seems, before the Government of the Marshall Islands and, indeed, even in his relationship with his cousin, the now resigned Cabinet Minister, Senator Richardson—misled you. Because certain matters were not checked, you were responsible for this failure and you made these false statements. From the contributions to the debate today it seems that your Government colleagues and the Australian Democrat senators do not agree with the Opposition's contention that this has sufficiently compromised the office of President of the Senate or that it is of sufficiently grave concern for them to vote in favour of the Opposition's motion.

I wish to add a new element to the points made by Senate colleagues that directly relate to the letter that you wrote and addressed to our embassy in Washington. I refer to the statement that you made to the Senate today and your relationship with the Prime Minister. Before I do that I wish to acknowledge three things that have been referred to at different times by Senator Ray, Senator Cooney and, I think, Senator Evans. The first is that for more than four years—and as an Opposition senator, I acknowledged this—you have served the Senate well as President of the Senate. Senator Cooney felt that a number of your critics did not put proper emphasis on the substantial way in which you have contributed to the tradition—a good tradition—of Presidents of the Senate and guided this chamber over the period in which you have been President. I acknowledge that you have done that.

Secondly, there is the question of writing letters of introduction for citizens of Australia. It is undoubtedly accepted by all senators that it is appropriate for the President of the Senate or for any senator to write appropriate letters of introduction, even within the terms of reference of what you were attempting to do, to help Australian citizens.

Thirdly, I acknowledge that the important position of President of the Senate carries with it, along with a priority responsibility for this chamber and for the whole Parliament, a very considerable responsibility in respect of international relations. I readily acknowledge the skills and knowledge that you, Mr President, have brought to that important aspect of your position.

The motion is before us today because Opposition senators do regard it as a matter of grave concern that the letter was written without sufficient due care. This kind of letter should not come from any of us, least of all from the President of the Senate. Frankly, my criticism is directed much more at a Minister of this Government who put undue pressure on his mate and party colleague, the President of the Senate—a person from the same right wing faction of the Labor Party in New South Wales. He brought with him his cousin, a businessman who also has connections with the same right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales. He put undue pressure on the President of the Senate to write a letter of introduction that would be helpful to his cousin in what in fact was a con job on the Government of the United States and the Government of the Marshall Islands for his own pecuniary benefit.

I have not heard anyone today, nor have I had anyone outside this place, say that the millions of dollars involved in this scheme were to the benefit of Senator Richardson personally or to the benefit of the Labor Party in New South Wales. No-one has made that allegation. Despite the mateship and the pressuring of persons to make it possible for Symons to have access to key members of the United States Government and key members of Congress, quite apart from Ministers in the Marshall Islands, I do not believe that there is any evidence to show that the millions of dollars that were supposed to be reaped from the scheme cooked up by the unfortunate Mr Symons, who is now facing trial in the court of the Marshall Islands, were to be received, confiscated or misappropriated by anyone other than Mr Symons and his partner. I have not heard any accusation that this was to the benefit personally of Senator Richardson or the Labor Party of New South Wales. But what is clear is that there is a mateship connection, a sense of obligation that I believe was used by Senator Richardson as a lever on you, Mr President. These sorts of pressures need to be so thoroughly resisted that no officer of this Senate and no officer of the Parliament will succumb to them in the future.

I believe that the pressure on you as President was not only from the former Government Minister, Senator Richardson. Pressure was also applied on 13, 14 and 15 May by the Prime Minister, another right wing member of the Labor Party in New South Wales and an immediate colleague and immediate mate. I take grave exception to the way in which the Prime Minister put pressure upon you as President of the Senate and I wish to refer directly to that now. On the first page of your statement to the Senate today, you say:

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 May the Prime Minister asked me to provide to him a statement . . .

That was dynamite. This was in the context of Senator Richardson fighting for his life as a Minister of this Government. In fact, he lasted only five more days. The Prime Minister, under the barrage of parliamentary questions, press questions, public concern and headlines in the newspapers, and knowing that Senator Richardson's future as a Minister in this Government was, if not doomed, certainly in the balance, at the same time as it came to your own attention knew that there was a false letter of introduction written by the President of the Senate on behalf of this con man—another one involved in the mateship of the Labor Party in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: It is understandable that the Prime Minister would want some account from those whom he thought bore upon the Ministers of his Government, but I reject any assumed right of the Prime Minister or of the executive government to put any pressure at all on the President of the Senate. The President of the Senate stands way above the Prime Minister or the executive government. The President of the Senate is responsible to this chamber of the Parliament in all his conduct.

What happened because of the Prime Minister's pressure swayed you to a line of action which I do not believe in retrospect you would now fully endorse. Let me ask you the questions now that I wished to ask had there been more than two hours for Question Time today. I ask these questions very sincerely. I would have put to you, Mr President, four questions. First, did you agree to report to the Prime Minister before you consulted representative senators of this chamber? You have clearly acknowledged that you brought your intention to respond to the Prime Minister to the knowledge of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and Independent senators. That is sufficient in terms of the number of senators to be consulted in the first instance.

I know that Senator Vanstone and some others who have not spoken wish that you had contacted every senator, but that is not practical. Where I agree that all senators should have received communication from you was when you actually gave the report. These days, with stream fax, it is no problem administratively to bring your own report to this Senate to 76 senators ahead of the Prime Minister or any member of the executive government. It seems from your statement today, Mr President, that you had discussions with the Prime Minister on 13 May and agreed with him that you would meet his demand. After that, and only after that, you consulted representative senators as to your action.

Secondly, did you seek the advice of the Clerk of the Senate before agreeing to report to the Prime Minister? Did you seek any advice from Senate staff with regard to the appropriate relationship between the President of the Senate and the Prime Minister? Certainly I will be dismayed if you did not consult the Clerk of the Senate or appropriate officers in the Senate so that you would be given careful advice to ensure that your position as President of the Senate was not compromised at the demand of the Prime Minister of this country.

Thirdly, what steps did you take to safeguard your independent standing as the President of this chamber of the Parliament, a position which is not accountable to the head of the executive government? Fourthly, why did you, yourself, not publish your statement but rather allow the Prime Minister, at his initiative, to publish the statement? Unfortunately, Mr President, the third page of the paper you put in front of us is a statement of the Prime Minister's, in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have today received the attached report from Senator Sibraa on matters relating to Mr Gregory Symons.
I will examine the report and await Senator Richardson's report on this matter which will be presented to me on Monday.

That was his statement here in Canberra on 15 May. The Prime Minister has published your letter to him and the two-page statement with the attached letters. I regard it as demeaning of the President of the Senate for the Prime Minister to publish his statement. I believe that, as President of the Senate, you should publish your own statement. I would have urged that your report on the Symons matter be addressed to all senators and that only a copy of that report to senators be sent to the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Your covering letter could have said, `Dear Prime Minister, in the light of your discussion with me, your questions of me, I send to you a copy of the statement that I have now circulated to all members of the Senate'. I do not want to be legalistic, or—what was it, Bob?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nitpicking.

—I do not want to be nitpicking. You know that I respect you and that I respect the position of President of the Senate. I want to ensure that no Prime Minister now or in the future will ever put pressure on you or anyone in your position that leads you to be portrayed as responding to the demands of the current Prime Minister of this country. You are the President of the Senate and your first responsibility is to the senators of this chamber. I, therefore, take grave exception to the way you were pressured on 13, 14, and 15 May by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and by the way he took initiatives that I believe embarrassed this chamber. I include those considerations in my support of the Opposition motion that is before us.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by referring to the Australian public. When we debated the failures of Senator Richardson, on the last day of sitting of this Senate, I was one of the senators who spoke. I remember that Senator Aulich spoke after me and concluded what was a long debate about Senator Richardson. Following that debate, Senator Richardson has resigned. I said in that debate that the people of Australia do not want parliamentarians or governments that support favouritism, cronyism, or any kind of special privilege for their mates. They want members of parliament and governments that are objectively fair to all Australian citizens, that act in the national good and not for some private, sectional interest. One of the common features of the whole Symons affair is that members of the Labor Party have acted like mates. They have acted in a way which has helped their friends at the expense of others, not only in this country but also, as it turns out, in the Marshall Islands.

I believe that those values of the Australian people and the expectations of the Australian people demand that, when we have before us a statement such as that which you have made in the Senate today, Mr President, we ought to remind ourselves of the values of the Australian public and what the public expects of us. We should put such an emphasis upon the important office of the President of the Senate that will strengthen your hands and your successors' hands to withstand those undermining of values and the kinds of pressures which you have experienced from your mate, a Minister, Senator Richardson and from your mate, a Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In closing the debate I must say that it gives me no satisfaction to have to rise from the chair to respond to this motion against me. In the five years that I have been President, there has never been any suggestion that I have not fulfilled the role of President to the satisfaction of all parties. As you would all be aware, these are very difficult circumstances under which to hold such a position, with the Government not having a majority.

PARA.TAB: I have at all times been conscious of maintaining the impartiality of the office and availing myself to all senators irrespective of political affiliations. My role, by necessity, has often been that of a facilitator to many of you. It saddens me that in this instance, this is the basis of criticism or part of the criticism that is levelled against me.

Throughout the entire period that I have been aware of my involvement in the Gregory Symons matter I have never tried to conceal any information relating to this involvement. As stated in my report, I received a copy of the letter to Mr Lamb on the morning of Saturday, 9 May. On Monday, 11 May and Tuesday, 12 May I considered the matter carefully with my staff with a view to formulating a response to the Senate. Bearing in mind my responsibility to the Senate, I contacted all party leaders and Independent senators at the first opportunity to advise them that I would be reporting to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) although the Prime Minister was mindful that I did not have to do so. This was on the evening of Wednesday, 13 May. Soon after handing my report to the Prime Minister, copies of the report were delivered to party leaders and Independents by facsimile on the afternoon of 15 May.

I do not intend to respond to all the claims made by Opposition speakers today as many of them have been covered by my colleagues. However, there are some key issues I feel I must address. Firstly, in response to Senator Newman, I wish to advise that at lunch time today I had my attention drawn to an anomaly in the adjunct to my report which was tabled by the Prime Minister on 15 May. The reference to 7 May is a typographical error. Quite clearly it should have read, `I have been aware since 8 May'. With that clarified, I want to confirm, once again, that neither I nor my office was in any contact on this matter with Senator Evans's office until approximately 6 p.m. on Friday, 8 May. Senator Evans's senior adviser contacted my senior adviser at that time and told him that he was aware of the Lamb letter. That was at 6 p.m. on Friday, 8 May.

Secondly, Senator Newman asked why my senior adviser did not brief me on the Symons affair on my return to Australia. Very simply, my senior adviser was away overseas with me and, moreover, was absent from the office on Monday, 4 May on what I think was sick leave.

Thirdly, I wish to respond to several speakers who raised the question of how I was aware of Symons's contact with Lamb. It is quite simple to explain. Symons was given Lamb's contact number on the 12th. My senior adviser spoke to Lamb the next day and said Symons would call. My senior adviser that same day spoke to Symons, who said he had already made contact with Lamb. The letter was sent one week later—on 20 November. All of this has been covered comprehensively in my reports which I tabled today.

As for my involvement in the matter, it goes as follows: although I would have met Mr Symons a long time ago, I did not know him well and I certainly had no contact with him for at least 10 to 12 years. As pointed out by Senator Robert Ray, I was never in Young Labor with Mr Symons; he is 42 and I will be 55 this year. I never held any position of authority or responsibility in Young Labor. To Senator Bishop, I can say as a party official that at no time was I ever in charge of Young Labor in New South Wales.

I had no reason to doubt Mr Symons's credentials, given the nature of the documentation shown to both me and my senior adviser at the time. I knew nothing about Mr Symons that could have led me to doubt this. I did not take any action other than through normal channels. I did not give Mr Symons any other contact in Washington, either in the US State Department or in the Congress. I merely referred him to a person in the Australian Embassy in Washington who regularly deals with similar requests from other Australian business people.

At the request of Symons I wrote a letter to Mr Lamb which was a follow up on the telephone conversation between my senior adviser and Mr Lamb. As stated in my report, the letter was drafted by my senior adviser based on the information provided by Mr Symons at the meeting and on the telephone the next day. It was never intended for any person other than Mr Lamb. According to Mr Lamb himself, it was a perfectly appropriate course of action that I took. The letter was not a reference. The letter did not give instructions, nor convey support for Mr Symons's proposals. I did not seek to deliberately misrepresent Australian Government policy or the President of the Marshall Islands.

Where I have readily admitted I am at fault, with the benefit of hindsight, is in the wording of part of the letter. But at no time—and I wish to stress this—between sending the letter to Mr Lamb and the present have I been contacted by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for discussion, clarification, information, correction or retraction on any of these issues. Having regard to my position as President, I did not engage in public debate, despite some of the outrageous comments and allegations made by Opposition members. I must make reference to the fact that Dr Hewson publicly stated that I had done a deal with the Democrats which would give them my seat. I do not know how I possibly could have done that.

Finally, I totally refute the imputation that my introduction of Mr Symons to Mr Lamb was in some way connected to my preselection to the Senate ticket, which was said this afternoon. For the information of senators, I knew long before 11 December—the date put forward by Senator Bishop—that I would be No. 3 on the New South Wales ALP ticket. The ALP preselection system is based upon proportional representation and it was always clear to me what my position would be. The three senators up for preselection had already reached agreement between ourselves. I had been No. 1 on the ticket the last two times and this time Senator Richardson was a Cabinet Minister. As I said, we have proportional representational voting. This is the sum total of my involvement upon which this motion is based. I reiterate that I have not tried to conceal my involvement and I have readily provided a full and frank explanation of my actions to the Prime Minister, the Senate and the public.

I say to Senator Teague, who was the last speaker, that I reject totally what he said. The Prime Minister asked me to give him a report. He also said that I was under no obligation to do so. I said I was happy to do so but I would also be reporting to the Senate at the first opportunity, and he put that in his statement. I contrast that with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in the House of Representatives, who said that the Prime Minister should stand me down immediately. Senator Teague knows that he has no power to do that. I did discuss this matter with the Clerks. I received careful advice from the Clerks on a number of occasions. I published my report to the party leaders and I gave it out to the press before the Prime Minister released his report. There was some one hour's difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regarding Public Service Determination No. 27 of 1992, the Committee has received a copy of a report from the Merit Protection and Review Agency stating that the relevant legislative position was inequitable, anomalous and unfair. The report suggests that the situation be remedied by changes to the legislation. This is a matter of considerable concern. I add that the determination in question was not made by the Minister but by a public official.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC SERVICE DETERMINATION NO.27 OF 1992

This Determination deals with recreation leave for members of the Australian Public Service. Clause 11 appears to correct an anomaly under which the existing legislation operated to the detriment of a certain class of officers to the extent of depriving them of credit for up to one week's recreation leave. However, it appears that this correction only applies to present officers of the APS. It does not apply to officers who retired before the date of the Determination. Therefore, clause 11 appears only to benefit some of the people affected by the anomaly. For the others, it appears that the anomaly remains.

This general matter was the subject of an investigation and report by the Merit Protection and Review Agency, a statutory body whose charter, among other things, is `to ensure that actions taken and decisions made in relation to a Commonwealth employee . . . are fair and equitable.' The report, which examined the position of an officer who is not covered by clause 11, concluded that the existing position was `clearly . . . inequitable', `obviously anomalous', `unfair and inequitable' and required amendment or other action to mitigate its past and future consequences.

The Committee is concerned that a subdelegate in the Department then made a Determination which not only failed to implement the strongly expressed findings of the MPRA report but also which may entrench the anomaly.

The Explanatory Statement is of little assistance, merely stating that the clause was a transitional provision which `clarifies' the matter. Clause 11 was also amended by later Determination, although apparently without affecting its substance.

The broader issues raised by the Determination are also of concern. Numbers of Public Service Determinations confer discretions upon public officials. In the past the Committee has raised the question of merit review of these decisions. The answer the Committee has received was that merit review was available by the MPRA under established grievance procedures. The Committee accepted these assurances and refrained from raising other discretions. It would be disturbing if the Department felt itself able to ignore reports of the MPRA and legislate to preserve unfair and inequitable anomalies.
COMPLAINTS (AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.58

This short set of Regulations provides that the standard of proof required in proceedings before the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal is proof beyond reasonable doubt, which is the criminal standard of proof. The Regulations also provide that this standard extends to proceedings which commenced, or to a matter which arose, before the Regulations commenced.

The Explanatory Statement advised that the purpose of the amendment was to repeal and remake a regulation which recent advice indicated was invalidly made. There was no advice on the reason for this. The Committee assumed it was because the repealed regulation was made in 1985 and lacked the authority which was expressly inserted in the parent Act in 1987. The Committee has asked for confirmation of this.

Next, and more importantly, the Committee has asked for detailed advice on why the criminal standard of proof was prescribed for proceedings before the Tribunal, rather than the civil standard of the balance of probabilities. The Committee accepts that this is a sensitive area, but given the nature of those proceedings it may well be that the rights and liberties of the public could be better protected by the civil standard of proof.

Finally, the criminal standard of proof extends to proceedings which commenced before the date of commencement of the Regulations. If the previous regulation was invalid then the application of the new regulation to existing proceedings raises the possibility that the present regulation could operate prejudicially. The Committee has asked for advice on this possible prejudicial retrospectivity.
DETERMINATION NO.1991-92/12 UNDER S.10 GI OF THE AGED OR DISABLED PERSONS CARE ACT 1954
DETERMINATION NO.1991-92/24 UNDER S.10 F OF THE AGED OR DISABLED PERSONS CARE ACT 1954

Determination No. 1991-92/12 formulates Community Aged Care General Conditions for receiving financial assistance under the Act. One provision provides detailed criteria for two public authorities to assess the needs of individuals. Then despite an assessment by these presumably expert bodies applying detailed criteria, the instrument provides that the Secretary may overturn such an assessment. There does not appear to be a requirement for either an authority or the Secretary to give reasons for an adverse decision. Also, on its face, this would appear to be a case for AAT review of such decisions. However, there is no indication in either the instrument or in the Explanatory Statement that AAT review is available.
Again, other provisions empower the Secretary, at his or her discretion, to impose sanctions on certain members of the public. It appears that AAT review may also be appropriate in this case.
In the above cases involving the exercise of a discretion by the Secretary it appears that the Secretary may delegate all of his or her powers to any officer of the Department.

Under another provision a recipient has to "show" that he or she has a certain level of income. There is no indication of to whom this must be shown, or whether there is AAT review of a decision that his has not been shown.

On another matter, the instrument provides in wide terms for a person to indemnify the Commonwealth and its officers. This indemnity includes the cost to the Commonwealth of defending or settling any claim, including those concerning motor vehicles, relating to the administration of legislative programs. The extent of this indemnity may be harsh and unreasonable.

Determination No. 1991-92/24 amends the General Conditions of Recurrent Subsidies and has provisions which largely parallel those of Determination No. 1991-92/12. The Committee is concerned about whether discretions provided in the Determination are subject to external, independent merit review.

This instrument also provides that if the Secretary varies an assessment then the variation has effect from the original date of assessment. If repayment is consequently required then such moneys are a recoverable debt. On its face, such retrospectivity operates to prejudice a person other than the Commonwealth and is consequently of no effect.
The Committee has asked the Minister for advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Government to control the dramatic and progressive blow out in the Budget deficit, and its consequent inability to fund its One Nation-One Job spending binge and its tax cut promises.

SPEECH.PARA: This urgency motion is not merely about the economic incompetence of this tired, accident prone, faction ridden, divided, hopeless Government and its hapless and helpless Prime Minister, though, heaven knows, it contains those elements in full measure.

PARA.TAB: This urgency motion is not just about economics, finance, Budget policy and Budget deficits; it is also primarily about people. It is about the Australian people—the people in the gallery listening to this debate and the people who may read reports of it; indeed, all Australians. It is particularly about those two million Australians whose self-esteem and livelihoods have been shattered by unemployment and underemployment, and about the families of those two million Australians whose hopes, aspirations and living standards have also been shattered as a direct fallout from the unemployment or underemployment of their fathers and mothers, brothers or sisters, sons or daughters.

This urgency debate is about the human misery and hardship that this Government has wrought upon the people of Australia, whether they be the retrenched textile or motor vehicle industry employees, the bankrupted small business people in my own State of Victoria, those desperate for new industrial development in Tasmania or those in rural and provincial centres throughout Australia. The list is endless and it is nationwide. No area has escaped the economic wasteland created by the devastating economic policies and the unbelievable administrative incompetence of, first, the Hawke-Keating Government and, now, the Keating Government. Virtually no Australian has not been touched in some way by the cruel policies and failures of this Government.

Let it never be forgotten that it is Paul Keating, first as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, who is the self-professed and self-confessed architect of this barren, devastated and scorched wasteland. It is the same Mr Keating who boasted that he pulled all the levers of economic policy, that he had the Treasury and the Reserve Bank in his pocket and that he was, indeed, the Placido Domingo of Australian politics.

I say to Mr Keating that the Australian people do not see him as a Placido Domingo; they see him as the Grim Reaper, the Black Widow, the pariah of Australian politics and the Australian politician who, on his own admission, alone and single-handedly brought this nation and its people to its knees. As Prime Minister, he now believes that he can change Australia and restore Australians and their living standards to the levels down from which he has deliberately dragged them by changing the flag and dropping the Queen. He believes that, if those tactics do not work, spending up big with taxpayers' money and then promising distant income tax cuts to those same taxpayers will do the trick. On top of all that, Mr Keating actually thinks that Australians may believe him.

I have news for Mr Keating. As he found during the Wills by-election—although he was hardly in the electorate long enough to draw breath, let alone learn anything—the people of Australia do not believe him. They have been cruelly deceived too often. They will never forget the promise of then Treasurer Keating two days before the 1990 election that the Government would not let there be a recession, only to find that within a few short weeks—but too late, because it was then after the election—Australia had embarked on its worst recession since the dark years of the Great Depression of the late 1920s and early 1930s.

This former Treasurer, this now unelected Prime Minister, has no credibility with the Australian people. They simply do not believe what he and his Government say any more. Simply, they have been deceived too often. They have been lied to too often. There have been too many broken promises and smashed hopes and aspirations. When Mr Keating says, `Read my lips: there will be tax cuts in 1994 and 1996', as is outlined in his `One Nation-One Job' statement, the electorate now knows that what he really means is, `Read my lips while I con you and tell you things you want to hear but which I know are undeliverable'. That is what the Australian people think about the integrity and credibility of this Prime Minister and his Government.

Nothing could better demonstrate the reason why Mr Keating and his Government have lost all credibility than the subject matter of this urgency debate. Let me take it in three parts: firstly, the failure of the Government to control the dramatic and progressive blow-out in the Budget deficit; secondly, the Government's consequent inability to fund the spending binge contained in its `One Nation-One Job'—Mr Keating's job—statement of 26 February 1992; and thirdly, its inability to fund the so-called income tax cuts in 1994-95 and 1995-96, which is up to four distant years away.

Responsible financing of the spending binge and the income tax cuts was never a possibility. In that respect, the `One Nation-One Job' statement was always dead in the water. The dramatic and belated revelation of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) a fortnight ago of a further massive and devastating blow-out in the current year's Budget and in the starting point for next year's Budget has so shot full of further holes the 26 February statement that, like a sieve, it has sunk to the bottom in the waters of impossibility in which it was always marooned. One should not perhaps have expected otherwise from this Prime Minister and his acolyte Treasurer.

The 1991-92 Budget and its outturn must rank as the worst in Australia's history. That includes the forecasts of its deficit. You will recall, Mr Deputy President, that we started off in the Budget Papers last August with an estimated deficit of $4.7 billion. In January, only five months later, the Government pushed that deficit estimate out to $5.3 billion. On 26 February, only a month or so later, it went to an estimate of $6.8 billion. It has now gone to a staggering $9.3 billion deficit, and that may not be the end of it. Who knows where it will end.

We have already had four estimates for the Budget deficit for this year. Certainly the Government does not know what the final figure will be, nor apparently does the Treasury. It is absolutely unbelievable that neither the Treasurer nor the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, knew in advance of the disclosure on 11 May—the day of the Premiers Conference—that the Budget deficit had blown out from the earlier estimate of $6.8 billion to $9.3 billion.

The matter was discussed in the Estimates committees weeks and weeks ago. Every responsible economic commentator in Australia had said that the deficit would be much larger than the $6.8 billion that the Government was talking about. Yet members of the Government seemed to be the only ones that did not know that that was the case and then expressed surprise when they had to bring out that deficit figure only a couple of weeks ago.

The sheer size of the deficit is enough to justify my earlier statement that the 1991-92 Budget and its outturn must rank as the worst in Australia's history. But that is only part of the story. When one examines the extent of the turnaround in the Commonwealth's budgetary position, the truth of my claim is unassailable. On the Government's own figures, there has been a deterioration in the Budget of $17.4 billion, or more than $1,000 for every man, woman and child in this country, in the last two brief years alone. Two years ago, in 1989-90, there was an $8 billion Budget surplus. This year, 1991-92, the Government now tells us that there will be a deficit of $9.3 billion, a deficit which is 100 per cent greater than it estimated at the time of the Budget last August.

The real situation is even worse because, as you may recall, Mr Deputy President, several fiddles were done in the preparation of this year's Budget—something that Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins and some of their well-known mates would perhaps euphemistically describe as creative accounting—which effectively removed a minimum of $4.2 billion from the true deficit on an accurate comparative basis. Therefore, the true situation is that the deterioration in the two short years since the 1989-90 Budget is a mind boggling and, more importantly, nation destroying $21.6 billion. That is almost $1,300 of Budget deterioration for every man, woman and child in a period of two years alone.

I am sure we all well remember the years of the Whitlam Government—the years until then of the greatest economic and financial incompetence and damage in Australia's history. The havoc that the Whitlam Government caused to the fundamentals of the Australian economy and the hurt it caused to Australian families and businesses are still with us in many respects. Australia has never fully recovered from those blows. The deterioration in our finances under the Whitlam Government pales into insignificance in comparison with what has happened under Mr Keating's rule as Treasurer and now Prime Minister during the last few years. The tragedy is that the Government does not appear to recognise the direct link between Budget deficits, rising unemployment and falling economic growth. The Budget's rapid progression into huge deficit over the past two years has been accompanied by a collapse in savings and investment, a collapse in production and an increase in unemployment to a postwar record.

On the Government's own record, how can we ever believe again anything that the Government says about the economy or, more particularly, about its forecasts? Certainly, there can be no credibility in the `One Nation-One Job' statement. The fact is that the One Nation figuring is in tatters. The promised income tax cuts, which were not large anyway—they were only about $8.5 billion, and that would be a handing back of the bracket creep that the Government was expecting of only about one-third, contrary to the announcement in the Budget—cannot be delivered, small though they might be. Even the Government has no idea how they will be paid for. On the Sunday program just last week, the Minister for Finance failed to rule out an increase in other taxes to pay for them. So did Treasurer Dawkins in the House of Representatives today. So did Senator Button in response to my question at Question Time today. He refused to rule out upward increases in taxes over the next few years associated with the required funding of the `One Nation-One Job' statement.

It is about time that Labor came clean with the electorate on this matter. Will there be an increase in the wholesale sales taxes to pay for the cuts in income tax? Will the so-called sales tax simplification legislation now in the Parliament be the funding gun for those income tax cuts? Is the proposed increase in the tax on takeaway food containers from 10 to 20 per cent that is in the legislation in the Parliament today a taste of what is to come from Labor? Is the new tax on plastic and rubber sheeting part of the grand and cynical plan for a raft of new taxes to buy the electorate off with an income tax cut down the track in three or four years time? If not, where will the money come from?

As I said, in his answer to my question today, Senator Button cast further doubts on the One Nation tax cut commitments and their financing. We cannot believe any of the figures, the commitments or the promises. Australians have had too much of broken promises from this Government to be fooled again. Perhaps it is just as well that the `One Nation-One Job' statement has sunk without trace. There are fundamental flaws in its strategy, in its assumptions and in its arithmetic. It provides its main stimulus at the wrong time. The main stimulus, according to the statement, comes in 1995-96. How on earth does the Government know that in 1995-96 one will want the maximum stimulus that will be provided in the One Nation proposals if in fact they were implemented?

The One Nation statement provides its main stimulus at the wrong time. It draws on national savings when the major objective of this country must be to increase national savings. One of the two fundamental problems with this nation is that we do not save enough and are not productive enough, do not produce enough, yet this Government is planning to draw down on the national savings by in excess of $20 billion over the next three or four years alone. Its inflation and growth rate forecasts have been rejected by every responsible economic commentator, including implicitly the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank several days ago.

Far from cutting taxes, as the Government promised in the One Nation statement, it will have to look for more revenue. When we take full account of the Budget blow-out this year, the huge increase in the starting point deficit for the 1992-93 Budget—that is the one that will be introduced in just four or five months—and therefore the increase in the starting point deficit for subsequent Budgets, and when we take account of the Budget fiddles to which I have already referred which occurred last year, there is a huge hole in the Government's One Nation figuring. On the most conservative of estimates, that shortfall is at least $23 billion. To finance that $23 billion hole, the Government would require—if the Government chose to take the sensible course of action of introducing a goods and services tax into this country—a goods and services tax of about the same rate as proposed by the coalition in its Fightback proposals but without the $33 billion of tax cuts equal to more than $4,000 each year for each Australian corporate and individual taxpayer that are the essential components of the coalition's package of reform.

The fundamental difference between the coalition's Fightback proposals and the proposals contained in the now dead—thank heaven—`One Nation-One Job' statement is that the inevitable consequence of One Nation is an increase in taxes, not a decrease in taxes, an increase in inflation and unemployment and a decrease in economic growth.

One Nation has been a monstrous deception from the outset. The figures do not add up, the assumptions are false and the strategy is wrong. The drastic escalation in the already massive deterioration in the Budget that has been occurring consigns the One Nation statement to the scrap heap of history. In doing so, it will also consign its author, Mr Keating, and his job, for which it was designed, to the political scrap heap along with the rest of his Government. In the interests of all Australians, that cannot happen soon enough. We have all suffered far too much and for far too long.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not need to speak to the motion as I will be making my comments on it in the body of my speech. The Democrats will not be supporting the urgency motion unless the amendment circulated is agreed to. We think that the amendment improves the urgency motion. It seeks to delete the juvenile reference to the catchcry of `One Nation-One Job' which has failed to stick, and the totally inaccurate categorisation of the limited spending initiatives as `spending binges'.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the substance of the matter. The Budget deficit was predicted to be $4.7 billion. This was, as usual, questioned by the Opposition, and Access Economics cast doubt on the accuracy of the estimates. We knew quite early in the year that the estimates were too optimistic. Mr Willis, during his short time as Treasurer, made the observation that something had to be done to get the recovery going. Then we had Mr Keating, and he set about doing something.

The One Nation economic statement, obviously in response to the initial success of the Fightback package, set out the measures which this Government proposes to undertake over the next four years to stimulate the economy and to win the next election. One Nation contained a revised Budget deficit estimate of $6.2 billion. We said at the time that many of the figures in the document, especially the growth and current account estimates, were hopelessly optimistic. We now have the revelation that Commonwealth revenue has collapsed even more than expected, and we are looking at a deficit in excess of $9 billion.

But the deficit blow-out is not simply due to any irresponsible spending initiatives in One Nation; it has come about because of, amongst other things, the collapse in inflation. This has seriously impacted on PAYE collections because of less bracket creep. Add to that the windfall that was expected with property income and the tax file number system which has not materialised.

There have been some additional discretionary outlays from the former Prime Minister's rather pathetic jobs statement and the One Nation initiatives. But this accounts for less than $1 billion of the budgetary blow-out that we are talking about. These additional measures include additional family payments, additional training initiatives and various infrastructure measures.We think all of these are worthy of public spending. They are not binges and we do not oppose them.

The total increase in outlays under One Nation is $2.3 billion, and most of this falls in the next financial year. But this represents only half a percentage point of GDP in extra spending. It is totally affordable and cannot accurately be classified as a spending binge.

Let us turn to the tax cuts. The tax cuts promised in the One Nation statement are another matter. These will cost $3.4 billion in 1994-95 and $5.2 billion in 1995-96. By 1995-96, the Budget is supposed to be balanced again because of the phenomenal growth estimates and other optimistic assumptions in the One Nation package. But the Prime Minister has admitted that the tax cuts are simply to be funded by bracket creep. His scorched earth, high interest rate policies have all but eliminated inflation at the moment, and the bond market is showing us that inflationary expectations are also declining.

This lower than expected inflation result and overstated growth forecast will mean that the One Nation income tax cuts cannot be funded. That is why we have sought to correct and amend the urgency motion. Indeed, it may be better if tax cuts are never delivered because really they are very regressive. Only people earning over $20,000 get any benefit at all, and such cuts further erode the progressivity of income tax scales.

However, we do not agree with the Opposition's fiscal policy either. Let us not get too paranoid about deficits in principle. The Commonwealth deficit and the State deficits are automatic stabilisers in the economy. At different points in the business cycle the public sector's budgetary position automatically adjusts. As economic activity increases, tax receipts tend to rise and social security outlays tend to fall, thereby reducing deficits or even moving a Budget into surplus. Similarly, as economic activity declines, tax receipts decline and social security payments increase. So it is absolutely normal that if economic activity is less than that which the Government estimated while producing a Budget, the deficit will be larger than originally estimated.

When the Budget was brought down, the Opposition complained that the $4.7 billion deficit was irresponsible. Does that mean that the Opposition would have delivered, and will always deliver, a balanced Budget? At the time, it was pointed out that this strategy—that is, a strategy of reducing government expenditure by about $5 billion—would have cost 46,000 jobs. Given the further blow-out to $9 billion, a balanced Budget would probably have cost about 100,000 jobs.

We might think this is a socially responsible solution. But the Opposition should learn from history. What it is proposing is a 1990s version of the greatest fiscal mistake in Australian history—the so-called Premiers' plan which was imposed on the Australian people because of the wishes of Australia's creditors, the ultraconservative and independent central bank which, by the way, the Opposition wishes to revive, and most heads of government in Australia. This involved a supply side solution to the weak economic activity of the Depression. Government spending was cut by 20 per cent—if in doubt, cut government spending! All salaries and pensions were reduced, as were public works spending and industry development programs. And what was the result? It was a total disaster. The Depression deepened and unemployment and poverty and their associated misery also deepened.

The Prime Minister at the time was the hapless Mr Scullin. We know that he came to power almost at the start of the Depression. He did not control the Senate, which was hostile to the new Labor Government. That was, of course, before the stabilising and responsible presence of the Democrats in this chamber. Mr Scullin did not have any power over the Chairman of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Gibson, nor did he have any credible contrary economic advice from the neoclassical solution which was implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this for you? Surely you don't believe it.

—Of course I do. Senator Panizza was around then, was he not? But we have learnt over time that there is a role for the public sector to step in during poor economic times. When private investment collapses, the correct response is for public investment in, say, transport, communications and public housing, to be increased to try to stem a total collapse in demand and to keep the economy in reasonable health. So we do not subscribe to selling everything off for one little boost, and cutting all government spending. In addition, there is the previously mentioned fact that the Budget is an automatic stabiliser and, as such, the underlying deficit will vary, depending upon the macro-economic environment.

PARA.TAB: We hope that our amendment to the urgency motion will be supported, because it makes the motion accurate. We do not support the balanced Budget nonsense that is intrinsic in all the Opposition's criticism of the Government. But I have to say that I am really relieved tonight that we did not see the usual appendage to motions imploring the Government to instantly implement Fightback. TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this urgency motion, which is the failure of the Government to control the dramatic and progressive blow-out in the Budget deficit and its consequent inability to fund its `One Nation-One Job' spending binge and its tax cut promises, is clearly identified by the figures that have been released recently as regards the massive blow-out in the Government's financial position.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button also claimed that the Liberal Party in this motion was hankering back to the 1960s. However, he selectively chose which years he produced to the Senate, completely ignoring—as Senator Campbell interjected—other years in the 1960s which showed a much lower Budget deficit as a proportion of GDP, mostly being of the order of one per cent.

Senator Button also put the argument that the blow-out in the Budget deficit was not due to a blow-out in government expenditure but rather to a loss of revenue. The blow-out in this deficit is of the order of $4.6 billion, yet the fall in revenue, on the figures that Senator Button produced, is only of the order of $2.6 billion. So quite clearly there is a significant contribution to the blow-out in this deficit as a result of a blow-out in government spending. Just two years ago in the 1989-90 financial year the present Government managed to achieve a Budget surplus of $8 billion. We are saddled with this disgraceful debt because the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been completely unable to manage or control the economy with even a basic, rudimentary competence. The Government and its advisers appear, to all intents and purposes, to have constantly underestimated the depth of the recession which they created. Now, only a couple of months later, we see another amendment to a massive deficit of $9.3 billion. So much for the Government's forecasting and so much for the Government's economic competence. What this really means is that the Australian economy has lost about $6 billion more in economic activity than the Government's own experts predicted. So the Government is collecting less revenue and is paying out more on expenditure, particularly on welfare benefits, than it had expected.

This legacy has been left to Australians by the obnoxious duo of the smug Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and an irritating former Treasurer and now Prime Minister who seem capable only of dropping eminently forgettable one-liners on the Budget blow-out such as `This is a deficiency for all the right reasons' when commenting on the extent of the blow-out. When they make comments such as that, how can the people of Australia take this Government seriously? They cannot and they will not. How can the people of Australia believe that the groundwork laid out in One Nation as a policy document will ever work? Of course, they cannot and they will not. That will certainly be demonstrated at the next Federal election due now in less than 12 months.

The spotlight is now clearly on the Government to demonstrate and establish how its One Nation statement can and will work smoothly, and of course the key argument of the Opposition in this debate is that the Government simply cannot do that. This massive blow-out in the deficit completely destroys the credibility and capacity of the One Nation policy document. Quite simply, the Government has its numbers wrong to the tune of $10 billion and its sums will not add up. This is quite significant in the context of the minor nitpicking that the Government has embarked upon with regard to the coalition's Fightback proposals where the numbers do add up and are quite sustainable, most importantly because Fightback, unlike One Nation, is fully funded through tax reform and cuts in Government expenditure. It is too late now for this Government to do anything to effectively enhance its reputation as an economic manager before it faces the people at the next election. It has been simply riding on the coat-tails of this now discredited One Nation statement.

How can the Government claim that One Nation will still be plausible when it is now nearly $4 billion or about 60 per cent worse off in terms of its budgetary position than it was when the statement was heralded with such pomp and ceremony about three months ago? In a short period of just 12 weeks, this Government's policy position is rotting, leaving the Government in real trouble. No amount of glib rhetoric or back-pedalling will now save the Government.

The Prime Minister's planned tax cuts, which were the gigantic carrot to be offered to the voters, have now paled into insignificance because they simply cannot be delivered, even if the Government were to remain in office—but, of course, it will not have the opportunity to deliver those tax cuts. On that basis, the motion that has been put to this chamber tonight by the Opposition is clearly sustainable. It warrants the support of this chamber, particularly the Democrats. I urge all honourable senators, but particularly the Democrats, to support this motion, which clearly sheets home to the Government the blame for its economic mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon Senator Short gave notice of a motion criticising the Government over a claimed blow-out in its Budget. It is clearly inconsistent and hypocritical for the Opposition to move a motion claiming a blow-out in Government spending when it conveniently forgets and overlooks its own appalling track record of financial mismanagement at the Commonwealth level. Honourable senators opposite had an appalling record in budgeting. The forecasts for their Budgets were way off track in relation to the actual outcomes. Of course, the most significant case in point was the 1982 Budget. Remembering that particular Budget, I oppose this urgency motion tonight.

—Senator Campbell was not here in 1982. I was not either, but I certainly took very great interest in the 1982 Budget, because the outcome was a massive blow-out compared with the forecast. —You know that is a furphy.
—That information is available in a book in the library. All Senator Chapman needs to do is go to the library and borrow the books on the history of this period. It was $8,000m for 1983-84.
—You know that was based on forward Estimates that would never have been applied.

—Of course, Senator Chapman was here, but he is now trying, as Senator Short did, to rewrite history by claiming that the 1991 Budget was somehow the worst from this point of view. PARA.TAB: The reality is, of course, that in government the Liberals could not deliver Budget surpluses. That was the fact of life of the Fraser-Howard Government. The reality is that, basically, the increase in the Budget deficit reflects a diminishing revenue available to the Commonwealth Government. That is clearly on the record. So 1992's figure, as we have it now, is well below those at 24.3 per cent. Of course, the Liberals want to have it both ways. They want to claim that the Labor Party is a high tax party. That is part of their rhetoric. But the reality is that, of this nation's gross domestic product, Labor is taking 24.3 per cent in revenue this financial year for the Budget; the figures for the last two years of the last Liberal Government were 25.9 per cent and 26.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:
