SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, today I bring before the Senate a Bill to implement the Government's foreshadowed reform of product liability. The Bill represents the culmination of a process of legislative development which began over 5 years ago.

The sorry state of Australia's existing product liability laws has been the subject of reports from the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Industry Commission. All accept that an irresistible case exists for updating and simplifying the existing law. We need a system which promotes economic efficiency and provides justice to victims who suffer loss caused by defective products.

Internationally too, the need to make a manufacturer strictly liable for its defective products has been recognised in the development and implementation in the European Community of the 1985 EC Product Liability Directive. Indeed, the EC Directive appears in fact to be the emerging international standard for product liability legislation. I understand that, in our own region, the Governments of Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are also showing a clear interest in introducing legislation based on the Directive.
In December last year I brought the Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 before the Senate. That Bill followed the 1985 EC Product Liability Directive in all important respects.

Despite the extensive debate on this issue which had already occurred, I believed it was important to allow all interested parties adequate time to examine the terms of the Bill before it was debated. I therefore decided to introduce the Bill in December as an "exposure draft" and allow it to lie on the table over the Christmas recess. I undertook to conduct a full and comprehensive process of consultation and encouraged all who had an interest in the Bill to examine it carefully and provide any comments which they wished to make.

I have since received a great many submissions from a wide variety of sources, including consumer groups, peak industry bodies, commercial organisations, businesses and interested members of the public. These were of great benefit in considering the extent to which the language of the Bill met the policy objectives. A number of the suggestions and matters highlighted in the submissions have been taken up in the further development of the Bill and I thank all those who have taken a genuine interest in this matter for their input into the process of the development of this legislation.

I have chosen to proceed with the changes to the 1991 Bill by withdrawing that Bill and introducing a clean Bill rather than by way of moving a series of Government amendments. As I stated in my second reading speech in December last year, I believe that this reform is the most significant legislative development in the reform of consumer protection in recent times. It will assist all those with an interest in this matter to have access to a clear, consolidated Bill.

Similarly, given the significant reforms introduced by this Bill, the Explanatory Memorandum is likely to be important in the development of the body of jurisprudence which will surround the new regime. It will therefore be beneficial for one definitive explanatory document to be produced to prevent confusion in the interpretation of the new legislation.
Features of the Bill
The key features of the Bill are as follows.

A manufacturer or importer of goods is to be strictly liable for defects in those goods. Goods are defective when they do not provide the degree of safety which persons generally are entitled to expect, taking into account all the circumstances including the way the goods were marketed or labelled, and the likely uses to which the goods will be put. This is an objective test: it is the objective knowledge and expectations of the community which determine whether a product is defective, not the subjective knowledge and expectations of the claimant.
The claimant will not have to prove negligence. The difficulty in proving negligence is one of the factors identified in existing law which can lead to injustice.

A product will not be held to be defective simply because a better, safer product is subsequently put into circulation. This should ensure that the regime does not stifle product development or innovation.

Where a defect in a product results in someone being killed or injured, or where an individual's property is damaged as a result of a defect in goods, the manufacturer or importer is liable to pay compensation for that loss without the need for the person to prove that the manufacturer was negligent.
The claimant will have to prove on the balance of probabilities that the product supplied by the manufacturer was defective, and that the defect in the product was the cause of the loss.

It is a matter of public record that my intention in introducing this regime is that Australian consumers who are injured by defective goods should be placed in a position which is no less advantageous than that enjoyed generally by their European counterparts in the same situation. While on paper the EC Directive places the burden of proof of all elements of the claim on the claimant, it should also be recalled that it was prepared on the understanding that Member States would continue to utilise their existing rules of evidence and procedure in dealing with cases brought under the Directive.

In practice this means that, in many EC countries (including United Kingdom, Ireland, Germany, France and Italy), claimants have the advantage of a variety of procedural and evidentiary devices which assist plaintiffs to make out their cases. In some countries, it is said that the effect of these local rules will go so far as to shift the burden of proof entirely on a number of key evidential issues.

In contrast, under this proposal, it is clear that the onus of proof on the issues going to liability remains firmly with the injured person. Nevertheless, it is the Government's firm hope that in applying this legislation in the Australian context the courts in this country will wish to acquaint themselves fully with both the emerging jurisprudence in Europe and these procedural and evidential matters. It is vitally important that the interests of consumers and manufacturers alike be protected by ensuring that the new Australian law operates in a manner which is consistent with the laws in the marketplaces of our major overseas trade competitors.

This issue will be the major challenge facing the courts as they come to terms with this new legislation. And, for reasons I will give in a moment, it will continue to be an issue for the Government and this Parliament.

The Bill provides a number of defences. Manufacturers will not be liable if they can show that the existence of the defect was incapable of being ascertained by any means (the `state of the art' defence), or where the defect came into existence after the product left the manufacturer's control. A component manufacturer can escape liability if it can show that the component was only `defective' because of the design, markings, instructions or warnings of the product in which the component was incorporated.

The manufacturer will also not be liable where the product was defective only because it complied with a mandatory standard imposed by a government. Where the sole cause of a defect was compliance with a mandatory standard imposed by the Commonwealth Government, the Commonwealth will be liable to compensate the claimant for the loss.
In line with the EC Directive and the recommendations of the Industry Commission, compensation can be reduced or disallowed to take account of any acts of the claimant which contributed to the loss.

The Trade Practices Commission will be empowered to take representative actions on behalf of one or more consumers who have a product liability claim. However, the Commission will be required to obtain the prior consent in writing of those claimants whom it is to represent.
Reference of issues to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

As I have already said, the Bill which was introduced last December followed the EC Directive in all important respects. However, I have never believed that the Directive represented the `ideal' product liability legislation. On the contrary, in many ways it represents the inevitable result of an attempt to achieve uniformity where a number of disparate interests are involved—a `lowest common denominator'.
Senators will be aware that the Bill introduced last year significantly differed from the EC Directive in three important areas:
.the period of repose was extended from 10 years to 20 years in the case of personal injuries;
.overseas consumers were given the right to sue Australian manufacturers of defective products; and
.a provision was designed to ensure an injured person his or her `day in court' where, it was reasonable to infer from direct and circumstantial evidence that a defect in the product caused the loss.

Opposition to these elements threatened to once again delay the introduction of this important legislation and perpetuate the inequities recognised by all to be part of the current system. And as I have already noted, injured Australians have already waited five years while this matter has been under consideration.

Rather than allow further delay to occur, the Government has decided that the best course of action is to remove the controversial elements of my proposal for consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

These matters can now be examined in an objective and constructive way by an all party committee of the Senate. This will provide the proper forum for those who have expressed concerns to articulate their views in a public way. It will also allow consumer groups to put their case publicly from a position of equal standing for the first time since these reforms were proposed. I am confident that in such a forum, a range of issues which have hitherto been the subject of misapprehension can be dispassionately examined and that the true balance between the interests of consumers and manufacturers will become clear to all.

I am satisfied that the enactment of these proposals will still represent a considerable advance for consumers and achieve my fundamental goal of getting the new foundations for product liability law firmly in place.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill primarily confers legal rights upon individuals to institute legal proceedings. No direct increase in public expenditure is required to administer the regime. There may be a need to consider increased funding for the Federal Court and the Trade Practices Commission if product liability becomes a significant part of their workload, but this is not likely to occur for some considerable time, if at all.

There may be costs arising from the imposition of Commonwealth liability for products which are defective solely because they complied with a mandatory standard imposed by the Commonwealth. The impact of Commonwealth liability for defective standards, however, is not expected to be great.

The Bill will ensure that it is the person who was responsible for putting the defective goods into circulation who will be liable to compensate those people who are injured because of the goods. This will benefit the whole community. There will eventually be some increased cost to business as a result of the new law. However, European experience under a very similar regime has shown that this cost will be almost imperceptible in the initial years and very gradual after that. The Bill will also undoubtedly encourage improved design, evaluation and enhanced quality control.

This Bill will not only create a more equitable system of rights, but will also improve Australia's overall economic efficiency. Australian manufacturers will be required to produce goods which meet this international standard as part of their push to achieve international competitiveness. I also believe that Australian consumers are entitled to the same level of protection as is available to consumers where the EC Directive operates.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industry Commission Report No. 22 is a very important report. It is the review of overseas export enhancement measures. It is the final report consisting of two volumes, the first being the report and the second being a very important volume of country studies in terms of the overseas export incentives given in several other countries.

PARA.TAB: The report looks at how governments of Australia's major trading partners and competitor economies encourage exports. It assesses the impact of the measures and considers any lessons for Australia. There certainly are some very important lessons to be found in this report. In particular, the report notes how the Government's failure to reform taxation is harming exporters. There could be no clearer endorsement of the coalition's policy to remove the raft of taxes, such as the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and fuel excise. In total, as the Senate would be aware, the coalition proposes to abolish $20 billion worth of such taxes which are so harmful to the competitiveness of our exporters. Under the coalition's comprehensive tax reform, exporters, of course, will also be exempt from the goods and services tax and, therefore, will be major beneficiaries of those reform proposals.

The report makes it abundantly clear that Australian exporters are being disadvantaged because of the Government's failure to lower the tax burden on business and introduce a broad based uniform goods and services tax. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Some taxes are imposed on Australian exporters that are not matched internationally, especially because of the prevalence of value-added taxes. The Australian tax system should not reduce export competitiveness more than is absolutely necessary. This means ensuring, among other things, that taxes on inputs used in exports are minimised.
In a further clear statement that a goods and services tax is essential to allow business in Australia to be competitive, the Industry Commission says in this Report No. 22:
Favouring exports by exempting them from indirect taxation is also common.
That is, in other countries. It continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to add my voice to the voices of many others in the community who object to recent changes in postal charges which have seen outrageous hikes in postal rates, particularly in rural Australia. Country people—those many thousands of Australians who, for a variety of reasons, choose to live outside the metropolitan areas—are used to not always having the full range and speed of services that their city counterparts enjoy. They are used to paying more for food and petrol and making the most of their long distance calls. They are used to not having convenience stores and, because of that, they resort to buying things by mail order. Most magazines and newspapers are bought and received on a mail subscription basis.

PARA.TAB: That is why Australia Post's recent changes to postal charges are so iniquitous to country Australians. Australia Post has introduced a new print post rate which has hit all magazine publishers in this country and affected the profitability of those companies quite severely. The charges have not just moved a little and bear no relation at all to the changes in the CPI. For example, a magazine that in 1990 cost 46c an issue to post, today costs 87c to post to metropolitan areas, 99c to post to country areas and $1.52 to post to interstate country areas.

Those most disadvantaged are country people. Over an 18-month period, the cost of mailing a magazine to country people has risen by some 223.5 per cent. How will any business absorb cost hikes of that magnitude? What family can afford to pay the additional costs? These families will now have to pay these additional costs if they want those magazines delivered to country areas. Why, after years of profitable service, is Australia Post now discriminating as to who gets cheaper mail and who gets dearer mail?

Last year Australia Post made a profit of $144m. At a time when inflation is at such very low levels, why did it feel the need to do this? Why does the Government allow Australia Post to hit country people so savagely at a time of record bankruptcies and depression? Every week in this place we see yet another example of rural bashing. The Government believes that there are two kinds of Australians—city and bush—and that there is no need to worry about the bush vote because the people in the bush do not vote for them. That is an indictment on this Labor Government.

Last week I visited the northern electorates of New South Wales. It is pretty evident what the Federal Labor Party thinks of those people. At present they might have Federal Labor members, but they certainly will not last. I travelled on what is supposed to be the national highway and the potholes were so large that a car almost disappeared down them. I spoke with some of the more than 40 per cent unemployed who have no jobs, and little prospect of getting jobs. That is the reality of country Australia today. Now they will suffer a further disadvantage by having to pay more for the mail and magazines they receive.

I condemn Australia Post for this, just as I condemn it for its campaign to close country post offices, which is just as insensitive. While some of these post offices may not be profitable, many others provide an invaluable service that ought not be denied to any Australian, irrespective of where they live in this great country of ours. The blame must be shared by the Federal Government, which has overseen these changes and which has not intervened to remove the anti-rural bias so evident in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing my remarks, I seek leave to table the document to which they relate, entitled, The Future of Australia's Forests: A Policy Statement Prepared by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document. I felt obliged to table this document due to numerous calls to my office following a discussion of its contents on a recent Lateline program on the ABC. Most of the callers expressed great concern at the fact that a document of such importance was being negotiated behind closed doors. The tabling of this document is designed to bypass such a flawed process and encourage public comment and discussion of its contents. It appears from information that I have gleaned from behind those closed doors that this process has been going on for some time and that it had already commenced whilst debate on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill was still taking place in this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: In other words, whilst the Government was attempting to persuade other members of this Parliament to vote for legislative resource security, it was also pursuing negotiations to impose a form of non-legislative or de facto resource security. My response to that coincidence is to suggest that, as the legislative option has now been defeated in the Senate, the Government cannot claim to have a mandate to pursue the non-legislative option. The community has indicated on many occasions its concern to see the protection of the remaining native forests in Australia. The Government should be pursuing policies to reflect that community concern, rather than doing secret deals to satisfy the short term, profit-driven demands of the timber and pulp industries.

As I indicated earlier, my main intention in tabling this document is to provide the public and interested community organisations with the opportunity to openly discuss the concepts raised in the policy statement. Hopefully, it could also encourage the Government to belatedly establish a proper mechanism for input from these groups and rectify the present failure in openness and consultation.

The Greens are committed to the concept of community consultation as a means of allowing the less powerful groups in the community the opportunity to participate in the decision-making process. On a matter of such importance as the future of Australia's forests, it is important that the Government does not limit input to the policy process to those with sufficient power and money to gain direct access to the decision-makers.

I will not comment in detail on the concepts raised in the latest draft of this document, but look forward to the opportunity to participate and provide my viewpoint when the community is given equal opportunity. However, it is appropriate to point to the major failings of the document, quite apart from the question of the policy formulation process. Just as there was a double-handed process of legislative and non-legislative resource security negotiation, there is a doublespeak approach in the tabled document. It adopts the language of ecological sustainability on the one hand, while advocating market-determined management practices for our native forests on the other.

The policy statement continues to stress the concept of resource security, but on an even wider scale than that of the failed legislation. This concept cannot be justified in the context of publicly owned native forests. Rather, those wishing to establish industries based on timber should be creating their own resource security by establishing plantations on privately owned and already cleared land. The major reason for the current push by the timber industry for resource security is its past and continuing failure to plan beyond the short term.

In addition, the document implies that it is acceptable to clear native forests in order to establish plantations. This concept is absurd. At the commencement of the policy statement it is acknowledged that:

SPEECH.PARA: While the clearing of forests for agriculture has contributed to Australia's economic and regional development, it has also incurred some significant environmental costs including a loss of species, reduced conservation values, soil erosion, and siltation, and in some cases a rising ground water table leading to salinisation and soil degradation. These environmental problems have resulted in a significant economic cost. Clearing has also led to a significant reduction in the greenhouse sink capacity of vegetative cover.

However, it then goes on to advocate further clearing for a new type of agriculture—timber plantations. Not only does this prejudice the ecological integrity of vast regions, but also it fails to acknowledge the role that timber plantations can play in restoring the ecological balance in areas already devastated by wholesale clearance of native vegetation for agriculture.

PARA.TAB: As a Western Australian, I am also concerned at the implications of some of the comments concerning forest management and protection. For example, the use of prescribed burning by the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia has been a cause of concern to many conservationists for a number of years. The recent loss of a large area of native forests in the vicinity of Northcliffe in the south-west of WA during a prescribed or controlled burn is totally unacceptable. We cannot, as the Federal Government appears to be doing, accept the forest management practices of CALM as being consistent with forest conservation and the protection of native flora and fauna.

The complexity and importance of the future of Australia's forests is too great to be pursued without extensive community consultation. In conclusion, I urge the Government to cease these secret negotiations on the future of Australia's forests and to implement a comprehensive public consultation process prior to the consideration of the final draft by either the Federal Cabinet or the respective State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September last year and subsequently, I addressed the Senate on the subject of the Australian Taxation Office's treatment of swap transactions and, in particular, on the timing of the tax impact of the cash flows that occur in such swap transactions. At the time, I recommended as an acceptable, though not preferred, position that swaps be tax accounted on a daily accrual basis. Up to that point, the Tax Office had been arguing that the cash basis was correct in law and, therefore, that that basis must be applied. However, after extensive industry submissions were made on the matter, the Tax Office has now acknowledged in a final ruling known as IT 2682 that its interpretation of the law was wrong and that daily accruals is now the correct method.

PARA.TAB: So, Mr Deputy President, you may well ask why I am on my feet again tonight. The answer is that in paragraphs 81 to 83 of the ruling the assertion is made that certain swap cash flows, specifically those paid and received in advance, should still be accounted for on a cash basis. I put to the Senate that this exception is bizarre and irrational and that, on the basis of reasoning in the ruling itself, supporting daily accruals is clearly wrong in law because the Tax Office's own logic elsewhere does not support this argument.

As far as the law is concerned, the ruling supports the daily accruals view on the basis of a sound analysis of the available law on the topic. The crux of the analysis is that the tax law supports in this context the accounting concept of matching, whereby the timing of the cash flows is irrelevant and what counts is the allocation of cash flows to various accounting periods. Thus, the ruling correctly states that it is not appropriate for a deduction to immediately arise because a liability immediately arises to make a later payment. The liability becomes deductible progressively as that liability is transformed into an expense of a future period.

For example, if a bank agrees to pay its investors 10 years' interest in arrears for a loan, that interest liability should be expensed evenly over the 10-year loan period and be deductible on the same basis. It is not deductible today when the liability arises, nor is it deductible in 10 years when the actual cash flow occurs. The court has accepted that when damages were payable in the event of non-performance, that fact supported an operation of the matching principle to spread forward the income recognition over, in that case, the service period.

As the Commissioner points out earlier in the ruling, failure to make a swap payment as contracted for gives rise to a damages claim. But what the Arthur Murray case may or may not have said is really academic, given the first 80 paragraphs of the ruling. The point is that the accounting principles set forth in the ruling do not distinguish between cash flows according to their timing. The basic thrust of the 1984 tax decision, which the Commissioner quotes at great length, is that accounting principles should be followed whether one is looking at a payment in arrears or in advance. That is the issue on which I am taking the Tax Office to task tonight.

That is the position that I have outlined in law. So it goes without saying, because it is self-evident, that the economic effect in terms of swap pricing is that this hybrid cash accruals basis will have an alarming repercussion because it involves an element of retrospectivity. That ruling makes matters worse still by giving this hybrid treatment of cash accruals a retrospective operation.

Thus, notwithstanding that the Commissioner has clearly accepted that he was wrong to disallow daily accruals accounting for swaps in the past, he nevertheless continues to insist that taxpayers who adopted daily accruals in the past—that is, the correct method—must recalculate their tax position by tax effecting advance payments and receipts on a cash basis. This is absolutely ludicrous. This is retrospectivity at work at its worst.

Retrospectivity is unacceptable to this chamber. I believe it is important that the Tax Office should acknowledge the practices and abhorrences that this Senate applies to this concept of retrospectivity. Therefore, in light of this dilemma, I urge the Senate to support the following: firstly, the consistent application of daily accruals tax accounting to all swap cash flows; secondly, a non-retrospective operation for the ruling so that taxpayers who consistently and correctly adopted daily accruals in the past should not have their tax position disturbed; and, thirdly, an amendment of the recent ruling to achieve the outcomes in both the first two recommendations. I urge the Tax Office to examine these propositions and to amend its ruling accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take about five minutes of the Senate's time tonight to comment on an international matter which is relevant to a number of Australian citizens. I refer to the murder in the last few days of Judge Giovanni Falcone, who recently visited Australia. He has had connections with Australia in terms of his longstanding fight against the Mafia elements that have dominated certain parts of Italian politics and which have been present in the Australian environment at times.

PARA.TAB: It is important that, wherever there are Italian citizens who constitute a major minority of the population as they do in Australia, this Parliament should make it known that we pay our respects to a man who was prepared to accept constant daily threats on his life over a significant number of years, who was prepared to take on the apathy over concern about justice that prevailed in many parts of the Italian political system, whose family was threatened on many occasions and who ultimately gave his life to ensure that justice prevailed in a country where significant parts of the regional governments that make up that very interesting country were free from the effect and control of the mafioso.

A number of us in Australia have been very interested in the developments that have occurred in the last few years in Canberra, particularly in relation to the murder of Assistant Commissioner Colin Winchester. The parallels are not exactly the same when one considers what has happened in Italy. Certainly, I never thought that I would grow up in a country where, for example, an extremely high ranking member of an Australian police force would be murdered in cold blood and that that murder, which appears to have been a professional one, would remain unsolved. There seems to be no indication that anyone is any closer to finding a solution to the problem. I never thought that that would occur.

The murder of Judge Giovanni Falcone is a timely reminder that in many countries, and even in a country such as this—which has enjoyed a relatively peaceful relationship between police and the community and which has enjoyed basically an ethos of a respect for the law—there is a determination on the part of law enforcement authorities to continue the hunt for those people who murder significant figures in the police force or in the judicial system. As I indicated, when Judge Falcone came to Australia he made it very clear whilst he was here that obedience to and respect for the law does not grow overnight. He indicated quite clearly that it is something that can be cast away very quickly with tragic murders such as that of Colin Winchester.

Tonight, I put on the record the respect that a significant number of Australian citizens, especially Australian citizens of Italian descent, want to pay to the efforts of Giovanni Falcone and the courage that he displayed in the face of what many say was an inevitable death—a threat which was ultimately carried out. On behalf of those people who believe that the tide must turn sooner or later in Italy, especially in Sicily, I say that our hearts and our support go out to Giovanni Falcone's successors in Italy, especially in Sicily, and that the people who take the responsibility for continuing his work there are supported by the Australian Government and by this Parliament.

I wanted to spend some time tonight reminding people that we are all citizens of the world. Especially in a country like this where we have a very large Italian population, we need to be aware of the pressures which exist on a number of those citizens. Giovanni Falcone did not die as just another personality overseas but as someone who had very direct relationships with Australia and who was intimately involved in ensuring that the criminals and the murderers who believed in the past that they were quite free to do what they wished would sooner or later be brought to justice.

The lesson for Australia that we ought to take very seriously indeed is that if one senior important policeman in this country is murdered then we have already approached that situation where the ethos surrounding law and justice that right will inevitably triumph and the concern that we have about people being brought to justice ought to impel us to ensure that an issue such as the Colin Winchester murder should not be allowed to simply fade in our memory. No matter what happens over the next few years, the people who murdered Colin Winchester should be brought to justice, irrespective of the costs or how much effort has to be put into it.

Tonight as we respect the memory of Giovanni Falcone, the message we ought to be sending to all the criminals in the community—and it should be very clear indeed—is that this Parliament, this Government and the citizens of this community will not rest until Colin Winchester's murderer is brought to justice. I do not think anyone in this place would argue about any amount of money that needs to be spent to achieve that. I thank the Senate for its time tonight. I want to indicate finally that, although this Parliament has not officially paid respect to the memory of Giovanni Falcone, there are a significant number of us here who would like to have that recorded tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What steps have been taken to align the Commonwealth with European legislation which entitles people to be compensated for loss of amenity to their land due to government projects (partially or fully funded), from noise, vibration, odour, loss of view and natural surrounds, even though their land has not been specifically acquired for the project.

(2) Are there numerous projects that this should apply to, including Riverview interchange in Brisbane, rail expansions in East Brisbane and, of course, people affected by the proposed third runway in Sydney.

(3) Is the Minister aware of the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission No. 14, presided over by Justice Kirby, addressing this issue and the suggestions to raise revenue for this compensation.
(4) Does the Government accept the thrust of this report.

(5) Will assurances be given to people affected, such as those in Riverview, that upheaval in their local community, and not just transport efficiency and road safety, will play a part in cost-benefit analysis of projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Lands Acquisition Act 1989 provides for the acquisition of land by compulsory process or agreement by the Commonwealth and those Commonwealth authorities to which the Act applies. Compensation is payable under the Act only where some interest or right in land is being acquired.
There is not specific Commonwealth legislation providing for a right of compensation of the kind which the question suggests is contained in unspecified `European legislation'.

(2) There are obviously many projects undertaken by local, State, Territory and Commonwealth Governments which, while providing essential public services and national infra-structure, may affect the amenity of adjacent landowners. Whether compensation should be paid is a matter to be determined in accordance with the relevant legislation in place. The policy issues with which this legislation deals are complex and involve the balancing of public interests and increased expense with the claimed damage suffered by those in the immediate proximity of the project. In many cases, the value of land can be increased by such projects.
(3) Yes.
(4) The Government's response to the Report was effectively contained in the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988. The subsequent Lands Acquisition Act 1989 substantially implemented the Report.
(5) As this project is not one for which the Commonwealth is responsible, the matter is one for the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 11 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was an agreement reached between the Federal and Tasmanian Governments permitting continuation of quarrying at Exit Cave, subject to acceptable limits on the scale and development of the operation.
(2) Did the Federal Government agree to pay compensation to the company should any limits subsequently be placed on the operation of the quarry.

(3) Was the Federal Government advised in November 1991 that the Exit Cave quarrying operation impacts upon the World Heritage values of the Exit Cave system and therefore on the Tasmanian World Heritage Area.
(4) What action did the Minister take to halt further quarrying and assess compensation obligations.
(5) Under what conditions did Benders Pty Ltd undertake blasting operations at Exit Cave quarry on 5 February 1992.

(6) Why did the Federal Government either endorse conditions for blasting, or expressly give permission for this blasting to take place, given that the Minister had been advised that blasting at the Cave impinges on World Heritage values.

(7) Was the Minister aware that when these blasting operations took place Benders Pty Ltd was negotiating with Pasminco Metals-EZ for renewal of the contract to supply limestone to Pasminco; if so, why were these negotiations allowed to proceed.
(8) When was the Minister advised that the Tasmanian World Heritage Area Standing Committee had concluded that continuation of quarrying at Exit Cave jeopardises the area's World Heritage values.
(9) Were Benders Pty Ltd and Pasminco advised of this conclusion.
(10) Was a recommendation, to the effect that quarrying should cease at Exit Cave, to be considered at a meeting of the Ministerial Council scheduled for 29 February 1992.
(11) Did Mr Cleary, Tasmanian Minister for Parks, Wildlife and Heritage, request postponement of the meeting; if so, why did the Federal Government agree to such postponement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) No. However the Tasmanian World Heritage Area Standing Committee was advised on 20 December 1991 that a hydrogeological survey conducted for the Tasmanian Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage indicated a link between the quarry and the Eastern Passage of Exit Cave in the Tasmanian World Heritage Area.
(4) I immediately agreed to the process for assessing the draft Environmental Management Plan (EMP) for Benders Quarry and sought advice on the compensation obligations.

(5) The single blast at Benders Quarry on 5 February 1992 was carried out under licence conditions as approved by the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning under the Tasmanian Environment and Planning Act 1973.

However I am advised that blasting of itself does not impinge on World Heritage values. My Department was involved in consultations with the Tasmanian Government on revised guidelines for this blasting operation. Licence conditions were modified to permit limited extractive operations under appropriate monitoring and within the previously agreed temporary limit of quarry operations up until 29 February 1992.

(7) I was aware of negotiations between Benders Pty Ltd and Pasminco Metals-EZ. The negotiations are a commercial arrangement between the companies and, as far as I am aware, are not site specific. Both parties are aware of the position with regard to Exit Cave.
(8) 25 February 1992.

(11) The Tasmanian Minister for Parks, Wildlife and Heritage requested postponement of the scheduled Ministerial Council meeting. I agreed to this postponement because there were matters requiring further consideration prior to a meeting of Ministerial Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 10 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) In light of the fact that surgery, as the primary treatment for cancer, has never been subjected to a randomised clinical trial with an untreated group as a control group, on what scientific basis can it be claimed that surgery is a proven method of cancer treatment.

(2) In light of the fact that trials comparing survival after different types of surgery for breast cancer have shown no difference in survival between radical mastectomies, quadrantectomies, lumpectomies and excisional biopsies for tumours up to 4cm, and in view of the greater degree of disfigurement and greater amount of psychological trauma for the woman, and the greater expenditure involved by health authorities, on what basis does the more radical surgical treatment of mastectomies continue to attract financial support by Commonwealth Medical funds.

(3) In light of the fact that mammograms involve x-rays which are known to suppress the body's immune system and cause cancer, what is the evidence that mammograms are beneficial and warrant subsidy by Commonwealth Medical funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Medical services, including surgical procedures, are included in the Medicare Benefits Schedule on the clinical advice of the medical profession. The Government does not itself conduct clinical trials in relation to surgical or other procedures in relation to the Medicare Benefit arrangements, but is advised in relation to such clinical matters by the relevant professional college or association. The surgical procedures for the treatment of breast malignancy continue to attract Medicare benefits because there are items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule relating to such procedures. These items will remain in the Medicare Benefits Schedule, and therefore continue to attract Medicare benefits, while they continue to have the clinical endorsement of the medical profession. It should be noted that removal of any procedure from the Medicare Benefits arrangements would not result in medical practitioners discontinuing with that particular procedure, rather it would remove the entitlement of a patient to a Medicare benefit. Furthermore, the actual treatment modality selected in any particular situation is a matter for the treating clinician to determine, having regard to the clinical circumstances of that case.

(3) The report `Breast Cancer Screening in Australia: Future Directions' (Australian Institute of Health 1990) concluded that "Of all of the methods of breast cancer screening which have been examined, mammography is the only method which has been shown unequivocally to reduce the risk of death from breast cancer screening. Screen-film mammography is the preferred technology for mammographic screening".

This conclusion was reached after a meta-analysis of the results of a number of overseas mammography screening programs including the Health Insurance Plan of New York study, the Swedish Two Counties or "WE" study, the Swedish Malmo Trials, and the UK trial of early detection of breast cancer group.

At the low radiation doses used in mammography, no suppression of the immune system has been shown to occur nor has there been any direct demonstration that these low doses lead to any induced breast cancers. Estimates of the cancer risk can be made by utilising data from women exposed to high doses of radiation and extrapolating to the low doses used in mammography. Calculations based on current Australian radiation doses and the proposed national screening protocol indicate that screening may result in a loss of life expectancy, at worst case, of about one half of a day.

A contribution of $100,000 was provided late last year to Australian community groups to assist victims of the Yugoslav conflict. Some of those funds were used to purchase and distribute foodstuffs to those in need.

A further contribution of $250,000 was provided in January this year in response to a combined United Nations appeal for Yugoslavia. Part of that contribution was to be used to purchase and distribute supplementary foodstuffs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will work begin on a new Defence White Paper.
(2) Will a draft or discussion paper be issued for public comment; if so, what public consultation programs subsequently will be undertaken; if not, why not.
(3) Will Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s be edited for public release; if so:
(a) who will edit it; and
(b) when will it be released; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There has been no decision to commission a new Defence White Paper.

(2) Since a new Defence White Paper has not yet been commissioned, I am not able to say whether its development will involve a draft or discussion paper. I would draw the honourable senator's attention, however, to the public documents that are already available on our defence planning and development. These include the previous White Paper, The Defence of Australia 1987; the Defence Corporate Plan; the annual Defence Report; and a wide range of speeches and statements by myself and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (including my major statement to Parliament in May last year on the Force Structure Review outcomes). In addition, the Government plans to shortly release an unclassified version of the current strategic guidance document, Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s. This has not been done by any previous government.
(3) Yes.

(a) Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s is currently being edited for public release. This is being done by officials from the Defence Department in consultation with counterparts in the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Prime Minister and Cabinet. Professor Paul Dibb from the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre at the ANU has also been involved in the editing process in his capacity as a consultant to the Department of Defence.
(b) It is planned to release the document shortly. There is no fixed timetable for its release.
